reviewText: This was not classic Bond it was better. The persona that Daniel Creg brings to the bond character makes James Bond more believable and more accessible.This Bond knows his job and that's all that counts.  Of course there is a bit of vengance mixed in with his pursuit of the Bad Guys, but saving crown and country are upper most on his agenda.If a few Bad Guys die along the way, so what they were causing problems anyway.  If Bond has to go off the reservation to accomplish his mission; then he gets a little Mavericky, the best M can do is hang on for the ride.  But she also knows that James will get results, and in the world of super spies that's all that counts.Award worthy entertainment, a must watch film of the highest caliber.

reviewText: After reading some of the reviews here I was expecting that this film would be all action and no story.  To the contrary, I think this is one of the best Bond's ever and part of that is because of the emotion Daniel Craig brings to Bond.  You can sense his barely controlled rage carrying him from scene to seen.  He is on the edge and this film takes on the journey to see if he will make it back or not.  The film is beautifully shot and you can tell how much hard work and effort went into it.  As with the Bond films of old, the locations are characters unto themselves and Bond is constantly moving from one locale to another.  One review mentioned the film was hard to watch because the camera cut from scene to scene so rapidly.  I think that is true in only one sequence.  The car chase in the beginning is definitely guilty of that and I was worried the whole film would be like that.  Fortunately, that is the only scene guilty of that.  I think they were trying to show a sense of chaos in the car chase but it was just too much.  But, once you get past that scene it is classic Bond.I think this film was better than Casino Royale.  The one thing I didn't like about Casino Royale was that I couldn't see why Bond liked Vespa.  Sure, she was an orphan like him but beyond that I didn't feel the connection.  In Quantum of Solace, I felt that Bond and Camille were a great match for each other.  I can only assume that Bond cared about her enough that he didn't want to involve her in his life and see her die because of it.  I hope she reappears at some point in the franchise.Kudos to all involved in the film. They did a masterful job brining it all together.  This is one of those films that makes me wish I had become a filmmaker.

reviewText: I understand why many were disappointed with this movie.  For one thing, the action sequences are particularly hard to follow; 007 almost always engages multiple targets and it's really hard to see exactly what is happening, and to whom it is happening.  All that aside, though, the plot was believable and enjoyable.  Craig's 007 is very businesslike, not much given to small talk, but I believe he is right up there with Connery.  Judi Dench is wonderful.  I definitely plan to watch this one again.

reviewText: The film begins with a car chase, the pursuer shoots at his target. The language suggests Italy. James Bond escapes again. [What insurance company does he use?] What is in the trunk? The music tells you this is not the classic Bond introduction. There is a short clip of a medieval festival. A captured enemy boasts they have people everywhere, then something happens. There is another chase through a tunnel into a crowded street. The action is frantic, like a cartoon. They find a lead to a suspect, James Bond will investigate. There is a short interview. "I don't have any friends." More action follows. Finally the story begins.There is another chase with motorboats. [A recurring event since "From Russia With Love".] Bond escapes again. "She's seasick." Bond uses the latest in cell phones. There is a plan to stage a revolt to grab oil leases. Does an opera provide a place to plot in secret? There is more shooting. Next a visit to Italy, then to La Paz, Bolivia. Is there a shortage of water? Did a monopoly buy it all? They visit a charity party. There is a surprise after Bond drives away! Next a ride in an airplane, and another chase in the sky. An incredible escape! "We are acting out of necessity." Does Bond bring bad luck to all of his friends? What about being in an elevator? Felix gives advice to Bond. Money buys political influence in every country. A fire breaks out to provide a backdrop for the action. Can they escape? Of course! Bond visits Russia to meet a man. "I never left." And so the film ends.My impression is there will never again be films as good as the original series from the 1960s. I'm amazed that they still grind out this series. I haven't seen them all so I can't say this was the worst. The story seems too complicated and detailed. Note the lack of futuristic gadgets that are ahead of the curve. The story about the monopolization of the water supply in a South American country is real. You won't read about it in your local newspapers. The choppy editing suggests action but the changing scenes makes it hard to follow the story line. There seems to be a harsher, angrier side to James Bond, as if he was "Dirty Harry" instead of the earlier suave gentleman. This film strips the veneer of respectability from James Bond to show him as a brutal thug who implements government policy no matter how many bodies he steps over.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I would not consider myself a dedicated Bond fan but, I believe, I watched all of Bond's movies either on TV, on DVD and, half a dozen of them  -James Bond Blu-ray Collection Six-Pack (Dr. No / Die Another Day / Live and Let Die / For Your Eyes Only / From Russia with Love / Thunderball) (Amazon.com Exclusive) [Blu-ray] - plusCasino Royale [Blu-ray] on Blu-ray. Quantum of Solace is the first Bond I actually watched in a theater because... well... the Blu-ray six-pack actually came with 4 free tickets :). But, let's cut down to the chase, so to speak.I happen to believe that Daniel Craig could become one of the best Bond(s) ever. He is very different from his predecessors, not easily recognizable for a Ian Fleming creation but, quite possibly, what is needed for a franchise that's been showing its age lately. Craig's Bond has a big heart, is driven by strong passions and, unlike most of his predecessors, he seems to be constantly struggling to reconcile the need of his doing what he is told vs. his inner urge to be doing what he feels it's right. No stiff upper lip for this Bond but plenty of explosive outbursts and an almost trance-like, relentless, perfectly focused fighting style, never letting up until the enemy is defeated or repulsed if not completely obliterated.Now, for the not so good. And, as good as our new James Bond may be, rescuing a terrible script comes pretty close to 'mission impossible'. Quantum is one of the weaker plots of the series. I will not reveal any spoilers but, when we see, toward the end of the movie, what all that killing and bribing and government-overthrowing was for... at least my conclusion was that it made very little sense. Too many characters are killed for no good reason and at least one main character who was a known and mortal danger to the big and evil guy was allowed to swing freely between the baddie and James.Of the lesser characters, M is on the rise and she gets incrementally better with every new Bond release, slowly evolving from the irritable place-holder, almost completely obsessed and self-aware by her gender to the intelligence professional and team player that we see in Casino and in Quantum. Q, on the other hand, is hardly noticed and the same can be said about 'the gadgets', not entirely absent but not a lot of them.Not revealing the plot, I believe that I can note that this is the second Bond in a row where James does not 'get' the girl at the end of the movie.My overall impression: Craig deserved a better script. Casino was a good one, Quantum should have been better but it's not. Inside the James Bond universe, unlike Casino Royale, this one falls a bit 'below average'. That would have earned it a 2-star score but Daniel Craig is so good, I feel compelled to add one for his performance so, it's a three-star.
summary: Daniel Craig is a great Bond, the plot is below-average

reviewText: I personally LOVED Casino Royale and LOVE this, its follow-up...we have a new great Bond series in the making!  That is, if you care for Daniel Craig, if you care for a whole new Bond series fresh with the latest in effects and cinematography, if you do not think Casino Royale cannot be followed with, and if you are not stuck in the past.  It is no surprise that about a fourth of people agree with me (five star) and another fourth nearly so (four star).  It is also no surprise that about a fourth were on the fence (three star) due to some bias or nostalgia that they needed to hold on to and the last fourth would not be convinced with anything no matter how good.As for Daniel Craig, I personally think he is the best Bond ever, even if a blonde (there are quite a few blonde Brits and not all of them are women, my father is one).  I also think a new Bond series is long overdue and this one more than makes up for lost time.  The effects and cinematography speak for themselves, they are outrageously good, particularly on Blu-Ray and with a great A/V system, far better than in any other Bond flicks.  And for those who loved Casino Royale I am not about to disagree with you, but I do think this movie is about as great of a follow-up to create a genuine and fabulous new series as one could possibly expect.  My expectations of this movie were very high and the Blu-Ray exceeded them, having me captured from the very beginning and leaving me thrilled for the next to come out!
summary: Excellent film, mixed reviews not surprising

reviewText: Unlike Casino Royale, the latest foray into the Bond franchise is more shoot-them-up than the plot-oriented, character-development fare its predecessor was. Daniel Craig is still surprisingly delicious as the MI-6 agent who goes rogue to save the world. This time around though, the opening sequence is the only state of events that holds undeniable attention and Bond's notorious sex life gets slim action. For the 007 purists, this movie holds nothing of interest; for those willing to be entertained at the movies there's a bit of charm and good, old-fashioned fun.

reviewText: The first of the Craig 007 movies was excellent all round: solid script, superior acting (for the genre) and outstanding direction and camerawork.  This second episode is atrocious.  It is difficult to exaggerate just how feeble this movie truly is.  Starting with the context-free car chase (Wow! A car chase! How original!) through to a disjointed rooftop chase - which must have been more interesting to make than it is to watch - through to an airplane chase... ho hum, another day, another chase to endure.  The problem is that without a real story and without pausing to let us get close to what the actors are trying to do, it's all just random noise and silly sequences.  Bang, boom, thud - and that's the sound of the audience slamming the doors on the way out of the theater or falling from their chairs in a catatonic trance.The second unit camerawork is pathetic - all jumpy cuts and disjointed sequences that rob the frenetic action scenes of any emotional interest and for some people may actually induce a migraine.  The script is flat. This movie feels like it was cobbled together from a third-rate video game.  The producers should have looked at the rushes early on and have replaced both the director and the second unit director post haste.  As it is, a lot of money was squandered to no good effect.  The only positive thing to say about this dire effort is that at least it is fairly short.We can only hope the third in the Craig series of Bond movies involves a director who is capable of producing something more than this amateurish juvenile film-school type of montage.  There's a world of difference between compelling and innovative camera work with tight edits and a disjointed mess of sound and fury that signifies nothing.  Much better to save your money and instead spend it on a copy of the totally excellent Il y a longtemps que je t'aime, even though you'll have to purchase it via amazon.fr because the US site doesn't stock it.

reviewText: Taking up the action literally minutes after the ending ofCasino Royale,Quantum of Solacecan not be fully enjoyed without considering it as part two.  It's a spectacular wrap-up of the loose ends, Bond on a heat-seeking mission of revenge.  Like others, I was a bit disappointed that it didn't have the same constant psychological gamesmanship that layeredCasino Royaleso satisfyingly.  HoweverQuantum of Solacedoes have a good story.  The problem is, despite the fact that the action sequences are relatively short, they're so sudden and edited so incomprehensibly tight, there's no time to regain composure between when the frenzy stops and expositional dialogue takes up.  The initial impression of the film is one of bewilderment.But there's no sense arguing that point.  You either liked it or you didn't.  Myself, even in the theater, I knew I was overwhelmed by the breakneck pacing, that I had been left behind like one of the corpses in Bond's wake.  I was eager then to take a second look, preferably in hi-def, where it'll probably at least look better than it did in the theater.  Well, it did.Quantum of Solace [Blu-ray] looked as good asCasino Royale [Blu-ray], with nearly the same abundance of interesting colors and textures.  Different fromCasino Royale,Quantum of Solacecontained scenes in vast arid locales, which provided some nice earth tones and wide vistas, all nicely rendered.  Some of it was startlingly beautiful, like in the crowded streets and long shots of the hillsides of stacked exotic tenements.  Each locale was marked with a distinct palette, instilling a kind of surprise when the scenes changed.  The picture was brilliant and sharp throughout.  And I want to mention, the story itself definitely made more sense.  If you're unsure if you liked it or not, see it again.  It's definitely a very good movie.  Definitely.As for the extra features, of course, you have the  Jack White/Alicia Keyes video and the two trailers.  Then there's the usual making-of documentary, with interviews with the principals, Marc Foster, Daniel Craig, and so on; along with stunt pilots, location scouts, and so forth.  There was a satisfying interview with and demonstration by the composer David Arnold.  Not so satisfying was the 44-minute compilation of  production blogs by some thirty-odd technical people, sliced into too-thin 1m10s lengths.  They were so short, they became uninteresting after a while.  But the rest is good enough.  The main thing was that the film itself was as good as I suspected, and the picture and sound were outstanding.  Now the story is complete.______________________________________________________________

reviewText: It's hard to talk about the Daniel Craig Bond, and particularly this movie, without using the word "gritty."  So, there you go.  Last summer, I read all the Bond novels in order.  Daniel Craig's portrayal of Bond is more like the Ian Fleming vision than any of the previous actors', including, even, Sean Connery.  This is easily the most sober of the Bond films.  Lots of exciting action, only over-the-top in the same way as are the action scenes, in say, the Bourne movies.  (And the fight scenes seem clearly to owe much to the Bourne films.)That said, to be successful, Craig is going to have to tweak it a bit.  We can enjoy a more serious and realistic Bond, as an offset to the serial nonsense which are the Roger Moore films.  But he can't be a total downer indefinitely.  We're going to want to like the guy at some point and we're going to need at least a little of that Bond humor.
summary: The Daniel Craig Bond is something new.

reviewText: Let me begin by saying this is a decent film.  It's not BAD, but it's not nearly all it could have been either, and the reason for that is that the makers of the film are falling into the same trap that killed Brosnan's last Bond outing "Die Another Day." -- too $@&% much emphasis on very elaborate and very flashy stunts and effects sequences and not enough on the plot and the story."Casino Royale" was a great film not because it featured the coolest effects and biggest explosions, but because it told a riveting story.  That's also why the first several Connery Bond films were great.  It's distressing to see that after hitting a home run with Craig's first turn as Bond, by getting back to good storytelling, they couldn't see that THAT was why the film worked so well and stick to that approach.  They make it look like they are lost as soon as they don't have Fleming's actual story to work from.At least they left out the science fiction gadgets, but they did give way too much screen time to the elaborate stunt sequences.  If they'd put half as much effort into plotting and story writing it would have been a far better film.

reviewText: 5 of 5 stars for the James Bond 007 action movie: Quantum of Solace. As with every other James Bond movie, you can expect rich big settings with grand sweeping action, exotic international locations and insanely big action. QoS is on par with other Bond movies but is not in my top 10 list.QoS follows the events following Casino Royale (the remake of a few years ago, not the comedy version of the 70's). Daniel Craig plays Bond in both CR and QoS. He is a good, though not great, version of Bond. I do like Judi Dench as "M". She is strong, solid and believeable in the role. The key point to this movie is a new secret organization which MI6 learns of the hard-way. The organization is named Quantum of Solace. QoS turns out to be primarily a "business" organization trying thru illegal means to extract extreme profits from a country. The story has Bond jumping around the world to chase after the bad guys. The downside to this movie is that QoS doesn't really form as a group and the "big bad guys" are not as grand as in other Bond movies.The Blu-Ray of this is stunning with extreme sound quality. Further it is packed with extra contents. I was wondering how they blew-up that hotel. Even with the limitations I mentioned, this is a 5 star movie and well worth the time to watch it.
summary: Daniel Craig continues the Bond tradition

reviewText: From the UK showing (4 stars out of 5):The Good Things*There are quite a few major action scenes with lots of stuntwork.  What few special effects the film has are used seamlessly.*Aside from the jittery action scenes, the movie has a good filming style.*The story (although kind of thin and convoluted) is interesting.  It has a lot to do with environmentalism and the role major corporations play in world politics and economics.  The lines between good and evil are blurred to some extent.  Overall, the movie offers some interesting things to think about.*Acting/writing are great.  The characters are interesting.  Bond's character shows some interesting new insights, particularly in showing the negative effects of his actions (the whole "everything you touch gets ruined" effect).*Excellent sound design.*Excellent titles design.*I like the music.*Look out for one scene that greatly resembles a famous scene from another Bond movie.The Bad Things*The storyline seems a bit convoluted.  It also won't make sense unless you see "Casino Royale" first, since it picks up where it left off and has some of the same characters.The Questionable Things*Even though there are a lot of neat action scenes, many of them are filmed with a very shaky camera.  It makes the scenes more intense and gritty in a way, but also makes it hard to see what's going on.  I'm not a big fan of it, but it has its merits.*Don't expect a whole lot of humor or wild gadgetry.In terms of style and story, this new Bond film seems to follow in the shadow of other modern espionage films like the Bourne trilogy or "Mission Impossible III." But unlike those, this film still retains the Bond character and closely follows the canon established in "Casino Royale." It focuses really well on how the character has grown and how poisonous he has become.  It also has some interesting content concerning the relationship between governments, corporations, economics, and a little bit on ecosystems.  Because of all that, I think this is a pretty interesting Bond film.  I still prefer "Casino Royale" as the best Bond film, but if you enjoyed it, this is a good follow-up.

reviewText: Even now I can't fully describe just how or why Quantum of Solace is an "inferior" Bond film, save for a fact that it seems to put more emphasis on one chase sequence or another in a gritty sort of way that would almost seem to step into the empty-headed vomit-inducing-camera-shaking of a "spy thriller" like the Bourne Identity, and yet manages to maintain its own identity (no pun) as a Bond film of this "new" Bond era.The main prevailing error or issue in the film is the seemingly gaping disconnect between two plotlines that run throughout the movie. The micro-story of Bond wanting revenge on -someone- (not even really explained who) over Vesper's problems leading to her self-sacrificing suicide, and the fear by M and MI6 that Bond is letting his emotions destroy his subtlety and skill as an agent, and instead opt to barrel through enemies aimlessly and kill anyone he wants (spoiler alert: he doesn't do any of that).While we are probably supposed to believe that Bond is driven to stopping Dominic Green (Matthieu Amalric) in whatever his dastardly plan with Bolivia is, the key issue here is that the two plotlines have almost no connection whatsoever, and that Vesper's sacrifice seemingly has nothing to do with Quantum or its schemes. I say "seemingly" because the movie very clearly shows the opposite, but does not show exactly HOW she has to do with Quantum's schemes. She's just an opaque plothole that may or may not be a red herring. Bond shows absolutely no emotion over her save for a few minor scenes, usually involving Mathis or Camille, of which there are not nearly enough of these to give any justification of this sense of a need for revenge.At no point in time is it ever explicitly explained or mentioned just why Bond is so "devoted" to stopping Dominic Green beyond the fact that it's his assignment to do so. Very early on it is revealed that he, along with Mr. White and countless others from big-name diplomats to nameless henchmen, are part of a secret organization devoted to -something- (not even really explained what). The only memorable line about Quantum is Mr. White joking to the degree of "Here we are afraid to say too much over the phone thinking the CIA and MI6 are listening in on every word when you don't even know we exist!"Aside from the seeming infiltration of people on almost every level in every organization criminal and political, in an almost sort of Illuminati sort of way, Quantum really does nothing but remain a nameless cloud over which it apathetically watches things happen and occasionally puts its own people out of their misery when they are on the brink of death and/or about to reveal too much about them or break them out of the situation. Even Mr. White gets away alive and unpunished.Dominic Green also appears to be so completely out of his element that everything about him just screams "nameless minion" from the beginning. He doesn't even seem to be sane, as he constantly fills the screen with bug-eyed expressions of frozen-stupid, like a mix of Barty Grouch Jr. in Harry Potter, and Grima Wormtongue in Lord of the Rings, only without as much to do. The only time Green appears remotely human is when he gives a speech or talks with a Bolivian general, in which in either case it seems clear that he's been prepped with a pre-written speech or protocol by other members of Quantum.Dominic's entire hare-brained scheme is also another dangling plot-hole in the making that never really seems important even though the entire movie is focused on it; it first throws off the viewer into thinking it involves exploiting untapped oil resources in a Bolivian desert, then is later revealed that there is no oil there, and that Green's plan is little more than to dam up the underwater aquifers in Bolivia and force a drought on the country, before literally pulling out and doing the same elsewhere while the international community deals with Bolivia's problems. There's nothing else in the plan aside from that, and I fail to see any conceivable way that this would make any lasting money beyond a few millions made screwing investors out of oil and pipeline money.Green proves on multiple occasions to be just as dumb and incompetent as a campy Bond villain of old, most memorably in which he is leaving an opera with a group of investors, and catches Bond in a hallway, after an earlier scene in which he ordered Bond to be killed. Not only does Green freeze up and stare at Bond for what feels like 30 seconds, but he proceeds to do absolutely nothing to stop him short of sending only two guards to have a shootout with him which obviously fails.What is then left in the film is a piece of poor exposition tied around multiple action sequences that ultimately have a sense of confusion attached to them. What is most stunning is how Casino Royale had viewers on the edge of their seat with the mere action of a POKER GAME and yet the colossal boat chases and roof-top acrobatics and down-hill car-flipping chases have people on the back of their seats, placidly staring and wondering what is happening, why it's happening, and when Bond will do something 007-y instead of just being a generic pawn in a gigantic action sequence that could just as easily be slipped into a bland straight-to-DVD movie without much trouble.In totality, there's barely half a movie here, with enough explosions and guns and fighting to fill in the rest for time, making it the shortest Bond movie, but nowhere near the worst, as the -potential- storylines set up for future entries are good enough on their own to not be a total failure.

reviewText: I may be extra harsh on this film because `Casino Royale' was such a blessed cinematic experience for me.  I was not in the least a huge fan of James Bond, but 2006 totally changed my opinion when it unleashed the brilliance that was `Casino Royale' (ranks in my top ten of the year and garners a Lead Actor and an Adapted Screenplay nomination from me at my personal awards, The Ellington's).  Because that film was so cleverly crafted, I expected a lot from `Quantum of Solace'.I wanted it to be bigger, bolder...better.Instead of building off the intensity provided by deep character development and genuine attachment to plot points, `Quantum of Solace' goes in a different direction and just merely offers the audience a briskly paced thrill ride with hard bodies and `Bourne' style action sequences.  I'm not saying that a good action flick is a bad thing, but when you have such a wonderful starting point it is disappointing to see them somewhat throw away all that they worked to achieve by reverting backwards and delivering something that just doesn't stack up.The films plot seems a little underdeveloped (the film is also about an hour shorter than `Casino Royale', which may be part of the problem) and so it becomes almost forgettable.  This is sad, because the film doesn't provide us with the character development needed to make the films plot unnecessary.  Daniel Craig does a fine job presenting us with a sour Bond, one that doesn't really need to develop because we saw him grow to this point so lavishly in `Casino Royale', but Craig is not the only actor here and Bond is not the only character.  The sad thing is that Bond is the only interesting one.  Vesper was such an exciting Bond Girl, and so when I see someone as beautifully dense as Olga Kurylenko's, Camille take her place I'm left a little brokenhearted.  There is no denying that Olga is a ravishingly beautiful actress, but Camille is such an underdeveloped beauty that she practically becomes nothing but eye candy.  I'm glad they gave her a character arc, but it really isn't much of an original one (very `been-there-done-that').  She has a coldness that I liked, but she could have done so much more had they really tried to flesh her out.Dench is perfect, as usual (love the inspired casting of this role), Jeffrey Wright is good, Gemma Arterton is gorgeous and Mathieu Amalric is sorely miscast.I know that this sounds rather harsh, and the film itself it not bad (I own it and will watch it again), but I just want to express my disappointment.  Maybe my expectations were too high, but I don't think so.  When you come out of the gate with a blistering and inspired take on a film franchise you have an obligation to back it up.  Look at what Nolan did with his sequel to `Batman Begins', or even what Raimi did with his sequel to `Spider Man'.  They took what they did in their first film and flipped it on its head, delivering to us an even better film the second go around.  They built on their original film.  Maybe the change in directors had a hand in this films fate, but there is no way that one can say that Marc Forster does any justice to Martin Campbell's `Casino Royale'.So, if I were to grade this film separated from `Casino Royale', grading it as if I never saw Campbell's film, then I'd give it a B.  It is entertaining, action packed and exciting, and the brisk running time makes it so that you never get bored and never have time to really notice that the film is lacking in any real emotional connection.  It is also no where near the campy stupidity of some in this franchise and so the plot never makes one want to throw a shoe at the screen.  But, sadly (well, sadly for this film) I have seen `Casino Royale' and so I cannot grade this film separated from its predecessor.  Having said that, I give the film a C+.  It should have been much better.Thankfully it's not `that' bad.
summary: Missing so much of what made `Casino Royale' so unexpectedly brilliant...

reviewText: I have to declare that for me, James Bond has always begun and ended with `Dr.No', `From Russia With Love' and `Goldfinger'. As such, I've never been much of a Bond fan, even though I've seen the vast majority of them at least once. I find the franchise childish and at times rather stupid and never terribly entertaining.However, with the EON re-boot of Bond in `Casino Royale' in 2006, I decided I'd have a go with Bond once more and see where it was going this time and I have to say, I was quite surprised by many of EON's decisions in that film.Frankly, none of the post Connery Bond movies have ever done anything for me and each of the 70's, 80's and 90's Bonds have been extremely forgettable, so it was refreshing to see Daniel Craig's gritty take on the character. Craig, for me, has taken the mantle of "Best Bond Ever"...not that anyone really held that crown before. Craig's Bond is an altogether more grown up character. Extremely brutal and cold and who in many ways believably acts like the spy/assassin he's supposed to be, albeit in an unrealistic "spy" premise anyway.And it's Craig's turn as Bond that saves the ridiculously named `Quantum of Solace' from being a complete failure too, but only just to be honest.The main fault of `Quantum of Solace' is its lack of direction. It doesn't seem to know where it wants to go. It suffers very much from the "difficult second album" syndrome. Something, that's destined to be an inferior to its immediate predecessor. Where `Casino Royale' was an effective, refreshing and even absorbing drama, it's sequel is a muddled and unclear affair, that seems more like an epilogue to `Casino Royale' than a proper sequel in it's own right. There are 100's of reviews here already outlining the basic plot (what little there is), so I'll not rehash that here. But needless to say the move starts directly after the events of `Casino Royale' and continues on following Bond's attempt to uncover the people behind the murder of Vesper Lynd, his squeeze from the first outing. Along the way he helps Camille Montes (Olga Kurylenko), a Russian-Bolivian agent in her character's sub-plot and uncovers her former lover, Dominic Greene's real motives behind securing a deal with the Bolivian government for a useless piece of desert real-estate.With such a paltry skeleton of plot, it's not surprising that the film clocks in at 1hr 40min. But the problem with such a short running time is that the plot points are never fleshed out to any satisfying degree and the film seems to end very abruptly too, with a real sense of "Oh...is that it?" `Quantum of Solace' really did need to be about 10 or 15 minutes longer, with a bit more expansion on plot.The plus points though are pretty much the same as `Casino Royale'. The aforementioned Daniel Craig's great Bond character is repeated, the movie largely does away with silly and redundant gadgets (which the world is full of these days anyway) and Bond doesn't bed everything in sight with tiresome distraction (although, it's not done away with entirely unfortunately). Also, Judy Dench reprises her role as "M" and that's bound to be a good thing.All in all though, `Quantum of Solace' ends up being just ok. But it's a very quick "ok".Empire magazine's Kim Newman felt that "...at the finish...Bond's mission has barely begun." I have to say I agree with that sentiment, which gives me hope for the next instalment.

reviewText: I've enjoyed both new Bond movies (Casino Royale & Quantum of Solace) with Daniel Craig as a "rougher" Bond; not as polished and more physical. He's believable as the type of guy that could punch the living daylights out of another agent, whereas Pierce Brosnan looked like he might chip a nail. Quantum of Solace is an interesting film that raises issues about power and energy and natural resources, plus the new Bond doesn't sleep with as many women and doesn't even get involved with the main character (woman) -- she's portrayed as more of a strong co-fighter of crime than a brainless bimbo. Strong action film; I plan to collect all the Daniel Craig Bond films.
summary: Daniel Craig is a great Bond

reviewText: Though it grew on me with subsequent viewings, I am still not convinced that Casino Royale was that great of a James Bond film. But it's hard to argue with success and it did wet my appetite to see how the Daniel Craig era will shape up. So now, with Quantum Of Solace, I get my chance.  This is the 22nd entry in the Eon series; a series that has really changed the way movies present pulp characters on a continual basis. So, the 007 films didn't simply spawn a whole genre of 'superspy' action films; you can easily make a case that the Bond films spawned all modern action franchises from Die Hard to Iron Man. But after years of excess, the series is trying to re-position itself as a semi-realistic, serialized story of Britain's top secret agent.Quantum Of Solace is in fact the first direct sequel of the Bond series. And it often feels like a feature-length closing action sequence that was left out of the previous film. Quantum Of Solace opens minutes after Casino Royale ends; throwing the viewer right in the middle of a killer chase scene that pits Bond's gadget-free Aston Martin against multiple pursuants trying to prevent him from escaping with the evil Mr. White as they race down a perilous mountain road. It's a short, but damn exciting scene that sets the tone for the whole film.  The title montage, set to a fairly descent Jack White song, is weaker than Casino Royale's, but has a certain minimalist panache we haven't seen in some time. Then, the film gets down to business.Not to belabor the little plot there is, Quantum Of Solace revolves around Bond's attempt to uncover the shadowy organization behind the death of his lover, Vesper Lynd. His efforts quickly lead him to Dominic Greene (Matthieu Amalric of Munich and The Diving Bell And A Butterfly), a shifty environmentalist whose motives are less than altruistic. What exactly Greene's plot is, outside of trying to control Bolivia's (!) water supply, is as unclear as it is unimportant. Amalric is a fine actor, but his Greene is basically a weasel who is no match for Craig: he won't be making any "Bond's Best Villain" lists any time soon. And suffice it to say, antagonizing James Bond turns out to be a very bad move for him. Especially this particular James Bond.I was critical of Daniel Craig's charm-free portrayal in Casino Royale, but he's definitely growing as a character here. Many critics focus on his constant anger, but this is - in fact - what this film is all about: getting past your anger and becoming a professional. So Quantum Of Solace continues Bond's development from "blunt instrument" to debonair gentleman spy we all know.  And Craig gets to slip in a little dry wit along with a good dose of brutality and butt whooping he's come to be famous for. It works for me, though I do hope that the following films let him relax and enjoy the finer things that have always been a part of Bond's DNA; this guy can really use a dry martini and a fine cigar, just to take the edge off.Overall, Quantum Of Solace is a lean and mean little film. Clocking in at under two hours, it's shorter than most Bond adventures and spends very little time on anything resembling character development or frivolity; basically taking the already streamlined Casino Royale formula and trimming even more fat. What's left is sinewy, dry and somewhat slight, though never boring.  Director Marc Forster is not as deft with the action as Martin Campbell, but I was always engaged. Considering Forster's previous films though, there are some sadly missed character opportunities (especially with the great Giancarlo Giannini and Jeffrey Wright, who are both given short shift here); which is puzzling.  And Bond's libido seems way down; he's much more into killing than screwing. Perhaps we should add a Viagra to that martini and cigar, throw in a couple of reasonable gadgets, add a few minutes to enjoy the beautiful scenery, and the next 007 entry can actually feel like a real James Bond film. As such, Quantum Of Solace is a solid B effort; an exciting action film, that barely seems to belong in the Bond series.
summary: QUANTUM OF SOLACE - AKA Casino Royale 1 1/2

reviewText: Quantum of Solace is a direct sequel to Casino Royale.  In the movie Bond discovers the existence of Quantum, is introduced to his longtime CIA friend Felix, and further develops his trust relationship with "M" (Julie Dent).  The movie is filled with nonstop action, car chases, shooting.The movie starts off right where Casio Royale left off and quickly introduces bond to Quantum (Spectre anyone?) and Bond is quickly whisked away to Haiti, South America, Italy, London and a slurry of exotic locales that is so typical of Bond.I found this installment gritty with a Bond which is decidedly more thuglike than the debonaire Connery or Brosnan but most certainly Daniel Craig as Bond is much more in tune with what today's audience demands of the character and the fact that there are so many homages paid to the original bond that it will keep traditionalists connected to the old bond.Overall, a solid outting.
summary: A Grittier Bond Pays Homage to the Original Bond

reviewText: In the last thirty years or so--say, roughly half the life of the Bond film franchise--it seems to me that the closer a Bond film stays to original Ian Fleming material, the better the film tends to be. Of course, this might just be me, because I'm a huge fan of the original Fleming Bond stories. And there are exceptions, of course--1977's The Spy Who Loved Me, for instance, managed to hold its own very well, as did 1995's Goldeneye. But when the producers stray from Fleming storylines, the plots often get so convoluted and tangential that they simply become vehicles for the next action scene. And when _that_ happens, I often find myself watching the scene and asking "What's the point?"That was why I raved so much over Casino Royale. Not only did we see Daniel Craig become the best Bond ever (well played, and faithful to the way Fleming wrote him)--dark, very dangerous, but polished and with a touch of humor--we also had a plot that's as close to pure Fleming as we've had since--well, since 1969's On Her Majesty's Secret Service (or maybe 1981's superb For Your Eyes Only). Plus, the action scenes were both spectacular and neatly grafted in to the plot. That's why I had such high hopes for Quantum of Solace.With this latest Bond outing, the initial signs were somewhat positive. The producers were using a Fleming title, which they hadn't since the 1980s if I remember correctly (unless you count Goldeneye, which is a nod to Fleming though not actually one of his titles). And they were using Craig again (how could they not? The man is perfect for the part). But sadly, the old pattern holds true. They got away from Fleming, and the result is the usual incoherence.Rather than Flemingesque, Quantum of Solace is actually a retread of an earlier Bond film--and not a good earlier film, at that. Think about it: Bond on a trail of personal revenge up against a Latin America would-be dictator . . . yep, you've got it: 1989's License to Kill, a non-Fleming Miami-Vice knockoff that wasted Timothy Dalton the same way that Quantum wastes Craig. And, as with License to Kill, the villains, location shooting (for the most part), and plot simply lack interest. The only positive glimmers are Craig himself and the superb Judi Dench, who is putting even more teeth into the role of M this time around than last. There's still the element here, as in many non-Fleming Bond films, of incompetence (or even buffoonery) in Bond's fictionalized MI6, but it certainly doesn't effect M.I will freely admit (as if I have to by this point in the review) that I'm a major Fleming partisan. But I also like a good Bond film, even the parts that aren't Fleming originals. But without some Fleming plotline that makes good use of Bond's character, a Bond film might as well be any old action films because (Carly Simon notwithstanding) others do indeed do action better these days, or at least as good. It takes Bond's character, as developed by plot, to make the Bond film distinctive.The producers showed, with Casino Royale, that they can do it. While they didn't in Quantum of Solace, here's hoping they do it again (dare I say get their mojo back?) in the next Bond outing.

reviewText: I'm sorry, but Daniel Craig just isn't James Bond. He's too serious, unfunny and too rugged looking. Pierce Brosnan picked up where Roger Moore left off, delivering those quick one liners with cool, dry humor, personality and smooth style (Timothy Dalton was also a dud, IMO).This movie has a good enough story to be a deserved part of the James Bond legacy, but it doesn't have the balance of action and humor that the old Bond movies of yore had. Too serious, not enough fun--blah.  Three stars since it fires on all action cylinders, but it could have been better.Another thing...M sends down a young, hot looking woman to drag Bond back to England. Hello! Like James Bond isn't going to manipulate her in his favor any less than any other hot chick?? That was a dumb part of the story. Now if M had sent Jaws down there to collect Bond, he might have been more submitting!

reviewText: Quantum of SolaceThough many die-hard bond fans rate this film as secondary, I would not even dream of doing so. This bond film is shot crisp and delivers the punch. The audio particularly in this DVD is superb. The video is in widescreen format. Craig is definitely in a class of his own. He really looks battered and bruised. The story is a direct continuation of "Casino Royale". Judi Dench is quite impressive as M. The heart and soul of the film is Giancarlo Giannini's Rene Mathis, the kind of man Bond might be capable of becoming, and one he learns something about himself from. One of their scenes is easily one of the very finest moments in the entire history of the series. The film is also surprisingly vicious - for perhaps the first time in a Bond film, innocent people on the street, are deliberately killed. It may not be a great Bond movie, but it most definitely is a Bond movie. Olga Kurylenko manages to shake off the ineptness of her former films, to be a more than adequate, but not an especially memorable Bond girl. Instead of being just a pretty face, Kurylenko, comes over as a truly original variation on the theme - mysterious, driven, highly capable yet vulnerable too. In Quantum of Solace, Bond is trying to convince M that he is not seeking revenge - he is seeking his quantum of solace, his peace of mind. He needs to know who he can trust, who his friends are. Quantum so Solace, isn't one of the great Bond films, and Casino Royale set the bar far too high for it to compete. But it's certainly not a disappointment if you view it, aware of the fact, and more gratifyingly, the similarities to "License to Kill" are merely superficial. The running time is never a problem if one understands that, like "From Russia with Love"; this movie is beautifully edited, throwing out all the overused 'Bondisms' to get down to business. The story sees Bond pursuing the organization he holds responsible for the death of his love Vesper (Eva Green) in Casino Royale. It turns out that this organization, Quantum, still unknown to MI6 is highly powerful and internationally connected and Bond stumbles on its plot to control Bolivia's water supply. It has one of the most relentless and gripping pre-title sequences in Bond history. The film isn't as humorless as some have complained: there's a lot of dry wit where appropriate and a delightfully playful game of cat-and-mouse with Bond and M in a hotel, but none of the outright slapstick comedy that dragged the series down during the 'Roger Moore-days'. Craig still owns the role impressively and Jeffrey Wright starts to come in to his own as Felix Loiter, this time round. All said and done Quantum of Solace is a very enjoyable film. It might not have the suave assuredness of the Connery films, but what it has is Daniel Craig who, and this is coming from a lifelong Connery fan, is hands-down the best Bond of the series next to Sean Connery.
summary: A Daniel Craig Film par excellence

reviewText: Worth seeing, but if you loved the lavish, over-the-top, 2006 production of "Casino Royale" you may be disappointed. The story begins immediately after "Casino Royale" ends and skips some of the Bond basics: the lounging elegance and wit, Miss Moneypenny, the fun high-tech gadgets, the opening gunshot, and the line "my name is Bond, James Bond." The result is a relentless series of chases, much like the last Jason Bourne movie (everyone says this, and it's true). On the positive side, Judi Dench has a larger role as M and she keeps turning up to banter with Mr Bond. Other goodies include a lean, mean, Daniel Craig, a lean, mean script (much shorter than "Casino Royal") and a cat-and-mouse chase around a floating opera stage in the middle of a live performance of Puccini's "Tosca." But the glamour, pleasure, and sense of mischief that pepper other Bond films are pretty scarce in this one. Gone, too, are the scenes from "Casino Royale" in which Craig could explore psychological drama at some length (the poker game, the torture scene, consoling Vesper in the shower). Keep your expectations in check and you should enjoy the ride. This film is mostly about revenge; not much solace here, but then perhaps that's the point.
summary: NOT THE TYPICAL "JAMES BOND STYLE" AS WE KNOW!!!

reviewText: James (this time Daniel Craig) is pretending not to be upset by the demise of his girl by an unscrupulous person, finds that that person is a part of a cabal of unknown origin or purpose. Now he must get revenge and dismantle the cabal before it dismantles the British secret service. On the way he comes across a girl, Camille (Olga Kurylenko) that may or may not be on his side but may also hold a secret of her own.The film as all the reasons one watches Bond movies. There is action and story and girls and global plots. Yet this film harkens back to the original Bond's where we had more acting and personal interaction. Not the snide attitude and out of this world gadgets taking front stage.  There are no gimmicks or weird bad guys, just a mystery with a twist and people just trying to do their job.  Most of the cast may be different from the other Bond movies, but you will recognize the characters.  When it is over you feel that you watched a real Bond movie, and you have.

reviewText: I too went to see this film because of the free tickets received with our classic Bond blu-rays. Thank the lord the tickets were free otherwise we would have demanded our money back.Nothing against Daniel Craig, he is a talented actor in some areas, but not as Bond. As one of the other reviews stated he is the most un-Fleming like Bond. Which makes him good, how? Bond should be Bond and in this movie he is a low level Jason Bourne action movie ripoff.But that is not the problem with the movie. The problem with Quantum of Solace surprisingly isn't the title and isn't the non Bond worthy star, it is the director and the guys from the Bourne movies that were hired to film it.The action scenes are a confusing mess. A really bad mess, there are times it is hard to tell who is doing what to whom, and even better yet WHY.To that point the plot makes little to no sense at all. Beyond the brooding, charmless Bond going after revenge for his suicided girlfriend.  (a foot note: she killed herself,it is nothing like when Blofeld murdered Bond's wife.)Holding a bankrupt 3rd world nation ransom is a good move. That is what Blofeld and SPECTRE would do right? Oh. That's right he wouldn't.. Why would anyone try to pass this plot off to the movie going public is the biggest mystery surrounding Quantum of Soalce.As it turns out the biggest insult was yet to come, the extras included in this Blu-ray are almost non existent. Where is the alternate ending the director talked about? Where are the cut scenes? Could there possibly be a directors cut of this film that has makes sense of the movie.No. Not on this edition which is ashame.If you (are among the few who) saw Quantum of Solace and liked it you should pick it up on Blu-ray, it will never look or sound better. If you thought it was Okay then wait for the inevitable second release which will contain the extras which will make it worth while.As for me I'm skipping this one and ordering the next wave of Classic Bond Blu-rays and if I want to see Daniel Craig in halfway decent movie I'll watch Casino Royale, on Blu-ray of course.

reviewText: James Bond is back!! I know a lot of people have said that for years and for many of the past few Bond films. But I haven't really dug any Bond movie since I was a teenager when The Living Daylights (1987) and License To Kill (1989) with Timothy Dalton came out. Pierce Brosnan just didn't do anything for me as 007. I also like some of the old school Sean Connery and Roger Moore Bond movies, like Goldfinger (1964), A View To a Kill (1985), and Octopussy (1983).But with Quantum of Solace (2008), director Marc Forster brought some depth of character and emotional darkness to Bond that's been missing for awhile. And actor James Craig is bringing depth to the character as well.  It's no longer JUST about action and sex. And I'm certainly not saying that Bond should not have action and sex, but I think Forster brought more to the story in a better way than director Martin Campbell did with Casino Royale (2006). Even though the "bad guy" storyline in this movie is weak IMO, I still really liked the movie. I think its a movie about Bond, and that's what really interests me.As with any Bond movie, the action and chase scenes are top notch. I especially love watching Bond zoom down the road in his Aston Martin. The car scene in Italy is gorgeous. I was surprised that the movie didn't start with that trademark "James Bond walking towards the camera and then shooting at us" opener. And no James Bond signature music at the beginning either. I'll be honest and say that I did miss that classic Bond stuff right at the beginning. But I'll forgive the director and still give the movie 3.5 out of 5 stars.The photography in the film is top notch, as is the production design.  I'm amazed at all the incredible architecture shown in the film, like in many recent movies. It's great to see cool buildings whenever possible.

reviewText: There are a lot of reviews on this movie, so many of you will probably not read down to this review. But I felt like I had to make a comment about the audio. Even though the case might seem to indicate English Dolby Digital there is no track for English Dolby Digital. The English track is only in DTS Master. If you have an older receiver as I do, that only has Dolby Digital, you will not get the full effect of the Digital Hi Def sound. It is some what of a disappointment, because the movie industry has standardization for audio on current movies released on DVD, which should probably also include Blu Ray releases, to be Dolby Digital. The sad part is that with the amount of storage available on Blu Ray, they should have made the default audio track Dolby Digital and an optional audio track for the DTS. I now get to go backwards in time and listen to the audio in Dolby Pro Logic.
summary: Good Movie true to the James Bond image

reviewText: Daniel Craig IS the new James Bond. He cemented that position with his opening volley in the 2006 release ofCasino Royale. A bit more hard edged. A bit more gloomy. But just as dangerous, Craig gives us a Bond we're probably going to enjoy for several years to come. We get the same tough guy here in QUANTUM OF SOLACE but with a story that has problems.The good is that it picks up right where we left off with Casino Royale. We learn that a secret organization threatens the very government that Bond works for. Even to the point of shots being fired at M (Judi Dench,Cranford) by one of her own double-00s.Bond, still pining and hating his old love Vesper, finds himself enjoying his work too much. Killing is becoming a habit ...and M and her superiors don't like it. But when Bond begins to dig up dirt on political higher ups, M pays quiet attention. It all starts in a third world country and Bond's fascination with a beautiful girl (no surprise there) named Camille (Olga Kurylenko). She's after the man who killed her family. Bond's after whoever it was who shot at M. Their two paths intersect in an unusual way: Bond feeling sympathy for her and wanting to help her get revenge. Her feeling a unique pull towards Bond's unflagging search for truth, regardless of the cost. All of this is taken up by an evil man named Mr. Greene (Mathieu Amalric,Munich) who's trying to control the world's most valuable resource (I won't give that away) while giving super-politicos whatever they want. But Bond is on to him, and with his help, Bond aids Camille in getting her revenge, while also getting Bond closer to Mr. Greene.The biggest issue with the film, however, is the multiple threads that intertwine with Bond's actions. They are confusing in the extreme, making the watcher wonder what, exactly, is going on at various times. For instance, during a scene when Bond has to kill a man who happens to work for the British government, we never learn why this man got involved in the first place nor even who he was working for (clandestinely speaking). There's also a hotel that runs on fuel cells that goes boom! yet we don't know why this hotel is out in the middle of nowhere nor what fuel cells have to do with the storyline (yes, I know that fuel cells run on hydrogen, which can be gotten from water, but it still doesn't explain why it was out in a desert and not, say, along a river valley or near the ocean). There are other threads that also lead nowhere, but I'll leave you to discover what they were should you choose to watch this.But make no mistake, it IS an action-packed, 007 flick in the vein of what we've come to expect from Bond films. But it's a bit overly complicated. Something to be aware of.
summary: Overly Complicated For A Bond Film

reviewText: I really like this movie. I loved Casino Royale. And this movie feels like an extention of that movie. Craig is again awesome as James Bond. I'm already looking forward for the next Bond Movie. I hope Craig stays on for a long time. One thing that has stayed consistant is the beautiful women. Quantum of Solace definitely has hot women. With that said, watching Quantum of Solace without having seen Casino Royale would be difficult.

reviewText: James Bond started out as a sophisticated and suave, charming man. He was able to not only out man his enemies, but also out wit them. He was the ultimate personification of a man, especially back in the 60's when the first film, Dr. No, was made. Obviously, times have changed and so have Bond movies. Gone is the gadgetry. Gone is the subtlety.However, this is a decent action flick. Lots of explosions, a plot that kind of makes sense and doesn't literally just lead from one battle sequence to another needlessly. Daniel Craig does a great job of being this new Bond, as he did in Casino Royale, but that is relatively easy considering all he has to do is work out and not make many facial expressions.Again, this is not a old fashioned James Bond film, and if you were a fan of the Connery, Dalton days, then you might be disappointed. This is the new generation Bond, made for a younger generation in order to re-boot the franchise. Unfortunately, this is just an ok movie, even by action film standards.Personally, I don't mind this new Bond style. If you can get over the symbol that James has come to represent, and simply watch it as an action movie that just so happens to have this guy who bears resemblence to another movie icon, then you can see it as an action film.

reviewText: the writers/driector or this one thought, "Well, let's just do one chase scene after another and forget about substance."  Lessee, we start out with cars chasing car, then man chasing man, then on to motorcycle chasing car (assault on the motorcyclist and steal the bike) for more motorcycle chasing car. On to boat chasing big boat then little boats chasing little boat....do you see a theme here?  I swear to you it seemed like the entire movie was merely a collection of various chase scenes with a little bit of story squashed in for filler.I like Daniel Craig as the new Bond. The addition here of Olga Kurylenko was pleasant as both she and Craig know their jobs and probably did the best they could with what was offered. Judi Dench has been the best thing that has happened to the Bond series in years and hopefully she will stick around to the bitter end.  Ah, speaking of which, we're back to the movie.  I've spoken of the lack of substance as the negative in this review. For the postive aspects, we do indeed have Ms. Dench, we have a great new Bond, and we have a more serious tone rather than the tongue-in-cheek of Roger Moore or the boring Timothy Dalton.  I really did like Brosnan and thought he suited that type of Bond film.  Craig is perfect for the rough hewn, far from perfect agent. There does appear to be tendancy to kill everyone with no regard for any kind of law (yes, I'm fully aware of the meaning of "licensed to kill", but still!)Honestly, I'm really hoping the next Bond will rely more on storyline and less on mindless action. Ms. Dench and Mr. Craig have a lot to offer and will a little help from the writers/director I'm sure we'll see a much better Bond film next time.
summary: Maybe because the first Craig .007 began with wonderful chase scene

reviewText: It's a strange title, I'll grant you that...but it IS actually one of Ian Fleming's.  FYI: it was not for a novel, but a short story -- from the same collection as "(From) A View to a Kill" and "For Your Eyes Only."  According to Wikipedia, Fleming deemed it to mean the absolute minimum amount of love one needed to maintain a relationship through strife and down times.And, while it's commonly regarded as the least of the three Daniel Craig Bond films, that's like saying it was your third favorite Christmas...I doubt most would give the experience back.  If one sits back and thinks about this movie, though, one discovers it does have a certain flavor unlike the others: it's darker, more negative (both in flavor and storyline) and, yes, it's a little more difficult to follow.  But what it does do well is advance the re-creation of this brand spanking new Bond.It's not going to hurt you to see "Quantum" as a stand-alone movie, but it works best as the second half ofCasino Royale.  This is particularly true in the sense of his avenging the tragic, emotional and traitorous betrayal that took place in the last half hour of that film.  But seeing both allows you to better see the arc of Bond's new characterization, one that already seems to traverse the third movie,Skyfall, as well.In "QoS," Daniel Craig's consummate portrayal is of a driven Bond--quite literally so, right from the action-packed start, as he's being chased down an Italian coastal highway by two Alfa Romeos full of automatic-weapon-wielding killers.  This, then, places "QoS" minutes after the end of "Casino," which closed with his capture of the man who now lays in his trunk (or boot, as the Brits say).  This man -- the nefarious Mr. White -- was behind the theft of the money Bond won from LeChiffre during the casino game (but how he escaped all those bullets is beyond me).What follows is a somewhat involved trail of chasing the money, all of which places Bond and compatriots upon the path of financier and faux environmentalist Dominic Greene, whose nefarious plans are soon to be revealed.  And our spy is not alone: he's been joined by a woman named Camille Montes, who is seeking vengeance against deposed ex-general Medrano, whose organization Greene is helping to get back into power in exchange for what seems to be a useless piece of desert--though we are soon to know more.So, yes: "QoS" is a bit complex, and there is much I haven't even hinted at.  And, obviously, there are all sorts of exotic locales: Austria, Bolivia, Italy, Chile, Russia, and of course England -- to name a few.  And there are some vintage Bond-isms: (SPOILER ALERT!) not only does he seduce a sweet British agent named (gulp) Strawberry Fields, sent to keep an eye on him, but she is found dead by way of being coated head to toe in oil -- an ugly death reminiscent of Jill Masterson's demise by gold body paint inGoldfingeralmost--eek!--a half a century ago.And CIA agent Felix Leiter is here again -- apparently the first time the same man has played Leiter two movies in a row.  Another returning character from the previous film is Rene Mathis, Bond's ally in "Casino Royale." Unfortunately, Mathis has been living in disgrace after being blamed for Bond's kidnapping at the end of that film, and he needs some persuasion to return to action.But in this recent triplet of Craig films, Bond is being reinvented before our eyes: while he enjoys sophistication, it is no fey affectation; given the rigors of the job, he feels it is his due, and probably belies his own past, one that will be given more play in the third film...SKYFALL.  The first film fitted him out as a tough, dogged, and fierce agent, but this second one is painting him as a cold, vengeful man who understands the efficacy of violence and the price it can cost.As proof, when a close companion dies under Bond's watch, he hugs the dying man closely, tenderly reassuring him as he passes.  Yet moments later, when this companion succumbs, he coldly dumps his body in a dumpster, claiming it no longer matters.It is an existential act that displays him as a man who lives by a code outside of society or even religion. Sentimentality comes at a price, and it is one from which he is doing his best to wean himself.  Certainly, Vesper's love mattered a great deal, one even a freshman spy knew was worthy of a decision, and in "Casino" he stayed true to her and divorced himself from MI6.  But, when that romance ended bitterly, Bond returned, hardened against the "mistake" of such an act.  From now on, nothing matters but the case.A perfect example of the dichotomy this code must deal with is seen in Bond's loyalty to the cause. In other words, finding what evil action Dominic Greene is perpetrating supersedes all others at present including his own: finding the man responsible for Vesper Lynd's death. When his dogged pursuit of Greene causes big repercussions, he is ordered off the case...twice. And there is no doubt about it: not only is he called off the case, he has his status as a spy suspended and M actually has him arrested.But this Bond is more dogged than that: in each case he refuses to obey that order, shedding the entourage of agents who escort him into an elevator as easily as shrugging off a jacket.  Yet he still thinks enough of his duty that he leaves the elevator and waltzes STRAIGHT BACK TO M and tells her to include in her report that agent Fields did her job to the best of her ability.It is interesting that while Bond thinks nothing of the agency's stranglehold on him, he cares enough that another agent's file compliments her.  And he seems unwilling to hold a grudge against the very woman who would attempt to have him arrested; quite to the contrary, he reports back to her at every significant point in the story.  At the end, having performed his duties better than anyone could have hoped M tells him he is back on the force, and his answer to her says it all: "I never left."So, while Craig's Bond shares many similarities with previous Bonds, he is no longer the wisecracking Teflon spy who slays his foes at most with difficulty, but never bears the scars.  No -- while this Bond may always get his man, his brutality is often matched by others', and he is often wounded physically, mentally and, as we have seen, romantically.  His wounds in this regard are obvious to all who know him well.  While he is told to forgive Vesper, as well as himself, for her betrayal and death, he still broods regardless, as if it is another order he cannot obey.I am an ardent Bond fan, and I love Craig's portrayal of him: he may be my favorite.  While the spy had undergone several humiliating transformations--particularly during the Roger Moore years, which I felt did him a disservice equal to Joel Schumacher'sBatman Forever-- I love where Craig and his screenplay writers (Paul Haggis, Neal Purvis and Robert Wade) are taking Bond.  The concept of re-inventing him in modern times -- effectively wiping out the entire series up to this point -- was brilliant, though risky.They have transformed him into a gritty, realistic and vengeful killer who with this movie is two-thirds of his way toward becoming the man we have come to know him as: a consummate field agent with ice in his heart. While that particular quest is only a side note to this movie, its accomplishment does serve to give him a...well, quantum...of solace.
summary: Not as Great as "Casino," But Still Very Good

reviewText: "No, Mr. Bond, I expect you to die." Well, he has. I detected serious illness in Casino Royale, and now he is gone. His replacement is a grim, humorless, unsophisticated thug who should be armed not with a PPK but with a spiked club. He shows no dedication to Queen, country, or right. He is quite repulsive. He goes, not to beautiful, exciting places, but to squalid collections of shacks and featureless deserts (which is a good place for him, I admit). His adversary is about as interesting as a bowl of porridge.  Ah, well. We have The Twenty (or 21, if you, like me, rather like NSNA). Farewell, James. A pity that the tiny hands of Cubby's successors could not hold your greatness, nor their tiny minds appreciate what made you great.

reviewText: Quantum of Solace marks a departure for the Bond franchise its a breaking from the formula that has worked so well through the years. The film has given up some of the gadgets and guns for a grittier approach to the spy saga and after a few viewings it works quite well.Daniel Craig returns as OO7 in a direct sequel to Casino Royale. In fact the story starts where the last film left off. Bond has a new adversary in the mysterious Quantum Organization. Along the way the plot takes us into revenge for the suicide of Vesper Lynd as possible motivation for Bond's actions. The plotting is more global this time and for the first time we get an environmental plot line. The girls are beautiful as always and Russian beauty  Olga Kurylenko as Camille does a great job as does Gemma Arterton as Strawberry Fields. Along for ride are the always impressive Judi Dench as M and Giancarlo Giannini as Mathis. As a villian Mathieu Amalric serves his purpose nicely though not as memorably as some of the villians of the past.After some initial problems getting the Blu Ray to load (which necessitated a player upgrade) I was quite impressed with the presentation. The photography by Roberto Schaefer is stunning as are the locations chosen by the team to film in. The disc is not short on special features. There are shorts on loction filming, the stunts, Marc Forster as director, a music video, and an expanded interview section called Crew Files that introduces us to 31 of the crew members who worked on the film.Hopefully the series will keep on improving.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Fete of DeathEven with Daniel Craig as Bond, "Quantum of Solace" (QoS) is not as good as "Casino Royale," one of the best of the gilt-edged Bonds.  "Casino Royale," by the way, is also Ian Fleming's best-written Bond novel.  "QoS" is still a rollicking good action thriller film.It stars Craig returning as the 21st-century, post-9/11 Bond, a blue-collar, Americanized, if you will, Bond.  Craig hasn't the suavity of a Roger Moore or a Sean Connery.  Craig is more a London thug clad in aSaville Row single-breasted suit than he is an upper-class Cambridge-educated Brit.Stripped of his gadgets in "QoS," Bond is a lean, mean, killing machine, a ruthless murderer who, like Vince Flynn's Mitch Rapp or "24"'s Jack Bauer, doesn't bat an eye when it comes to torturing, or, for that matter, whacking the enemy.I found the opening car-chase scene difficult to follow, difficult to perceive because I couldn't get my bearings what with the quick cuts, jump cuts, and all-around jerky camera work.  The frenetic scene, however, did set the tone for the film to come--basically an extended chase scene that lasts throughout the length of the film.  Bent on revenge, Bond single-mindedly tracks the man responsible for his lover Vesper Lynd's death.  That is, "QoS" takes up where "Casino Royale" left off.The director Marc Forster makes a lot of use of crosscutting in "QoS" to effectively enhance the suspense, as in the scene where Bond is chasing the Quantum agent who is a mole in Britain's MI6 (aka SIS) and serving as M's bodyguard, no less. Forster keeps crosscutting between the chase and the horses racing outside--and then Bond winds up chasing the enemy into the horse race."QoS" is one of the better Bond films, but it's not in the same league with either "Casino Royale" or "Goldfinger," the Bond movie that set the standard for all 007 films to come.Another difference between the new Bond movies starring Craig vis-a-vis the earlier Bond movies is the final showdown.  In the preceding Bond movies, there is the requisite army of good guys converging on an army of bad guys in a massive, free-for-all shootout.  In "Casino Royale" and "QoS" Bond for the most part goes it alone.  This is especially true in "QoS" where he is considered a rogue agent by M who wants him put out of action as a loner with a grudge.--Bryan Cassiday, author of "Fete of Death"

reviewText: Ugh, they've ruined Bond. A perfect example of our anti-male times. Sean Connery's Bond was cool, sophisticated, and smooth with the ladies, but the most important part, he was completely unapologetic about it. No groveling and apologizing for being a man. He was a "womanizer"...so? He loved women, enjoyed being with them, and they loved him back. What's the problem? He treated them kindly but didn't take any crap from them.They began pecking away at Bond when Pierce Brosnan stepped in. I liked Pierce as Bond, but as soon as I heard M say "I think you're a sexist, misogynist dinosaur", I knew we were in trouble. They had to knock him down a few notches because we can't have a confident, guilt-free man walking around like that.Now with Daniel Craig, we no longer have a man we can look up to. He's just another charmless, humorless movie thug. All Bond's qualities have been stripped from him by the feminist tyrants and their p-whipped male enablers. Bond was ours, and that bothered them. One less male icon guys can admire, and we let it happen.
summary: Another male icon destroyed by feminism

reviewText: While I loved Casino Royale this film wasn't as good.  Entertaining, very new and fresh approach- as I've never seen a Bond film pick up where it left off in a previous film.  The action was good, the acting great and the story...okay.  Different, but it was a little flat.  Maybe because the running time was so short.  Casino was well over 2 hours and this one was barely over an hour and a half.  Not much wiggle room time wise.  The cast was great though.  I would recommend this, even though I wasn't quite sure how I felt about it after it ended.  I thought, before I went to see it, that I'd want to see it again.  Not so much.  It was nice because it filled in the blanks that Casino left, the whole Vesper--boyfriend being abducted...then she allows herself to drown.  The freaky dude, Mr. White.  Left me scratching my head at the end of that flick.  This answered those issues and vindicated Vesper and what Bond had with her.  Anyway, it was good.  Nothing overly special or spectacular.
summary: Good...not as good as Casino though

reviewText: UGH!! I was SO disappointed! WHAT HAPPENED? Same writers who worked on Casino Royale (which is probably the best Bond film ever)... seemingly good director, but it just failed on so many levels. First, not Daniel Craig's fault. He's AWESOME. He makes the thing worth watching at all, but the script just wasn't great and it wasn't a great story to begin with. What's it missing? Well, the spine of a great story and good characters and scenes to ornament it. Casion Royale had it because it was based on IAN FLEMING's first and, arguably, best book (particuraly the 2nd half of the movie which follows the book and not the rather pedestrian first half which had Purvis and Wade's mediocrity-by-the-numbers-writing written all over it).Solace is a straight revenge "story" (using word lightly here) and oddly mirrors License to Kill. That was Timothy Dalton's 2nd and final Bond movie... which, while good, didn't really have a Bond feel... civilized high living world replaced by 3rd world, south of the border, with our secret agent out to kill the bad guy on the run from his own service. License did have a completed script at least.I think Solace starts with a great opening in Italy and ends with a good scene in Russia... both of which make you long for the film to have followed along those lines. But it doesn't. The rest of the film is just kind of boring, not suspenseful, no chemistry of character and only momentary flashes of good dialogue (thank you Paul Haggis, but not quite enough like Casino). Like everyone says (and is apparent from the moment the film begins), it's a straight steal of the Bourne movies in tone and style. That would have been okay had there been better writing.Everything gets less and less interesting, while you're hanging on hoping it will come together... but by the time Mathis enters (returns) in you're pretty bored. Mathis' whole presence induces sleep... time that should have been spent with story and character development of those already introduced (probably one of the women and Bond's relationship with them).Other LOWLIGHTS: Title sequence which was done by the Director's "own crew." They say they love the 60s feel and From Russia With Love, but they made it 70s feel and no where near as good as all the recent title sequences by whoever that (talented) gentleman is. Coupled with the crappy title song (derivative, boring, pretentious... kind of like the director you say?), it serves as a warning for what the audience is about to see.That opera-thing scene where the director went "artistic" and did inter-cutting instead of staying with Craig, substituting suspense with PRETENTIOUSNESS.The final "showdown" with that 70s(!) style lair being blown up in pointless and again, yawn, suspense-less fashion. It's even hard to remember more about the movie...PRODUCERS: Fire Purvis and Wade, only use Haggis for dialogue. Get new, great writers (it's a BIG WORLD... they're out there!). You say you want new and great movies... well wait to you have a GREAT STORY and SCRIPT again!!! Then get a great director (I do like some of this guy's previous films too, but he just didn't work in this area- keep with that effort though). Personal plea: BEG John Barry to do another score! LISTEN to the title song before picking it (don't just go with White and Keys because they're supposedly cool). You cannot wait 3 years either... you have to make up for this!!!!! Craig won't be young forever!! GIVE HIM ANOTHER GREAT SCRIPT! YOU CAN DO BETTER THAN CASINO ROYALE, BUT YOU HAVE TO GO WITH STORYTELLING AND SUBSTANCE, NOT JUST STYLE AND TONE!!!
summary: I so wanted to love this movie, and I thought everything was falling into place...

reviewText: Is it good or bad? It depends on what you want.THE GOOD- The fighting scenes are exciting, quick and deadly. Sometimes, they're too quick to see clearly.- There many interesting stunts and special effects. For example, the scene where James Bond made the motorbike rider flipped 180 degree on his bike and hit the ground.- Non-stop action from the beginning till the end.THE BAD- There's no sentiment, no love.Even when human feelings are depicted, they're shown like cold facts not like touching moments. For example, Olga was scared stiff when the room was on fire after she shot the general. She's so scared that she forgot to try to escape. One of the reasons she's terrified because it reminded her of the moment where the general killed her father then set her house on fire. To soothe her, James Bond, just hug her and spoke to her in one or two sentences. There's nothing touching about that moment at all. I don't know why.In short, this movie is worth watching because of the action. That's the only reason.
summary: Is it good or bad? It depends on what you want.
