reviewText: Shooting, driving, and flying its way onto the big screens with what seems to be about a car-trunk full of adrenaline, the twenty-second James Bond film has arrived, though some would consider it only the second in a 007 franchise that is so new and much-improved that it hardly resembles its previous films. It follows two years after "Casino Royale" jump-started a flagging series with a reimagination of the origins of a British secret agent who is authorized to kill, the clandestine government organization he works for, and the gorgeous women who pass through his action-jammed life.Given this situation and the fact that a major part of the storyline in this film, "Quantum of Solace," is a continuation of the previous Bond offering, comparisons between the two, it could be argued, are inevitable. My personal take is that, after that last explosion blows, the last gunshot is heard, and the the dust finally settles, "Casino" is the better of the two, although "Quantum" doesn't sit on its laurels either. To the contrary, a case could be made that the action sequences of the latter are a touch too fast, with such extensive use of jittery camera moves, fast editing, and jump cuts that audiences may become confused as to what exactly is happening on screen, who just plunged off the cliff in his car, who's winning or losing. Until, of course, the action ends and the winner stands before our eyes.Of course, the winner is always Bond, and that's not giving away anything. From the very first installment of the series back in the sixties, if he sometimes loses a battle--which is rare--he always wins the war. Some things may change, but that is a formula which, despite Bond's makeover, does not change. There's still international intrigue, loads of bullets shooting through the air, numerous chase sequences that are improbable but entertaining nonetheless (lots of high-octane chases way-up-high and even more that fly through the air in more ways than one), some huge balls of explosive fire, and no lack of action in the bedroom, as 007 flies, drives, and boats all across the globe. And, there's an elaborate opening title sequence (designed by Daniel Kleinman) that summarizes it all to the tunes of a song featuring a famous singer (this time around, it's Alicia Keys), all capped off by Monty Norman's famous James Bond theme. In retrospect, all the usual trademarks are there save for one, which I'll let you figure out when you see the film.As usual, the plot, in its complexity, defies easy summation of its details, save for the simple premise: Bond seeks his own brand of justice for the one woman he had genuine feelings for, Vesper, who was killed in "Casino Royale." Could Bond be revealing his softer, more caring side? As played by Daniel Craig in his second go-round as 007, we see a little bit of that--but just a little. He remains largely the tough, rebellious man's man of before, continuing, when he deems it necessary, to upstage his boss, M (the fine-as-always Judi Dench), while trying to foil Dominic Greene, a business man (Mathieu Almaric, great in a bad-guy turn that is both subdued and intense) with evil designs for an extensive patch of Bolivian desert. The exotic woman at the center this time is Greene's former girlfriend, Camille (Olga Kurylenko, attractive in an earthy sort of way) with whom Greene is, one may say, on the outs. After all, trying to kill her has become something of his personal sport. If you think she and Bond wind get together, you're right; she's very much his type: the femme fatale. She plays hard to get at first, but he wins her over. (What did I say before about his always winning?) Thrown in are the exiled General Medrano (Joaquín Cosio) of Bolivia, a former enemy of Bond named Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini), and a couple American CIA agents (David Harbour  and the underutilized Jeffrey Wright) who work with Greene in an odd arrangement--or do they?All of the more memorable scenes are action segments: a high-speed car chase on a highway in the hills, the cars darting in and out of clogged traffic; a chase through buildings and on tiled rooftops in Italy; action jumping between boats in the water; spying, chasing, and fighting during an opera, while remaining unseen; an airborne assault over the mountains; and, toward the end of the film, two explosive fights intercut with one another.Despite the entertainment value of the hyperkinetic set pieces, I wish the writers (Paul Haggis, Neal Purvis, and Robert Wade) and director (Marc Forster, stepping in after Martin Campbell's eminently successful direction in the last film) had given Bond a few more chances for us to better glimpse his soul, as was the case in "Casino Royale." The basic premise would seem to offer just such a chance to make the character a bit more three-dimensional, but the filmmakers don't seize on it, preferring to focus much more squarely on action, somewhat to the detriment of how much we care about the character.Nevertheless, it is an engrossingly-juiced-up-enough entertainment with its high-contrast photography (by Roberto Schaefer) and the aforementioned style of editing (Matt Chesse, Richard Pearson), even if the whole thing, while still meeting the high standard of the new and improved Bond, does, in the end, feel just a bit routine. But, I suppose that's just the nature of the franchise, to some extent, a nature that is more apparent without the novelty--and diversion--"Casino" had as the first Bond film to reinvent its central character as an appropriately muscular strongman, jettisoning the increasingly unbelievable gentility and preposterous gadgets of before in favor of impressive high-concept stunts tempered with no-nonsense body-strength and combat.

reviewText: Background: For me, Daniel Craig is a very good Bond: He brings an intensity and physicality to the role that is good fit to the current version of the character (action hero, special ops, not English gentleman).All of the action sequences were not just disappointing, but boring.  The opening car chase didn't have any elements that hadn't appeared countless times before.  And the frenetic cutting created emotional detachment (I felt I was watching it from a distance, rather than in the middle of it).  Similarly for the foot chase (Casino Royale's was infinitely superior).  The airplane chase is so much less than what appeared in earlier Bond movies.  For sophistication and elements, I would place it in the 1970s--lacking the innovations of the 1973 TV movieBirds of Preythat was the aerial classic untilTop Gunin 1986.The exploding building insulted the audience's intelligence: No one would build a hotel where a small fire would be able to cascade to engulf the whole building within minutes. From the story, it appeared that the fuel was hydrogen (which has a very characteristic flame), but what was portrayed was the generic exploding building that you have seen in so, so many movies. The only unique aspect was the architecture, which counts for nothing.No plot: not enough plot points for this movie to qualify.No villain: Greene is just banal, but not even "the banality of evil".  It's a "paint-by-number" role that resulted from the writer inserting a placeholder and forgetting to come back and fill it out.Cardboard characters: Casino Royale showed a more complex Bond. The script provides little opportunity for Daniel Craig to repeat, much less expand on that.  The substitute is a bad guy telling Bond "You are both damaged goods".And M repeatedly condemns Bond without even bothering to ask what happened.  The formula is that M highly values Bond because of his ability to get results but is exasperated by some of his means to those ends.  This movie omits the former until the very end (a totally unmotivated change).The killing of Strawberry Fields is the most telling instance of lack of understanding of the formula: The woman to be killed by the villain is a close associate of his--typically a mistress, but the wife inTND--who has been seduced by Bond into betraying him. Fields is not that, and her role was too innocuous to warrant a targeted sadistic killing (she was a MI-6/SIS clerical support person sent to be a minder for Bond).Why 1 star? For a random film, being annoyed, but not deeply offended, by having my time wasted rates 2 stars, but I expect a higher standard from this franchise.  But it was more than a waste: This movie left me with a very bad "aftertaste" that I can't really describe, but which several friends said that they too felt.
summary: Making Bond boring; No feel for action or the formula

reviewText: Continuing the pattern set with Casino Royale, the producers and director of Quantum of Solace have firmly established that this is not "the same old" James Bond. Thank god. The franchise had progressively gotten more and more stale with it's established routine of action sequences, beautiful women, and resolution in which Bond wins the day and saves the girl. Quibblers might not be happy with the fact that there is no complete resolution at the end - we still don't know much about Quantum or who's behind it - but this is similar to how Spectre was handled (albeit with far less suspense) in the earlier Bond films with Sean Connery. I didn't think they could possibly top Casino Royale; I stand corrected. Quantum is now my favorite of all of the Bond films, followed closely by Casino Royale and the best of the Connery/Moore flicks - Goldfinger, Dr. No and Live & Let Die.

reviewText: It was bound to be tough to match the runaway success of Casino Royale, but this doesn't even seem to make an effort. As generic action pictures go, it's fine: the screen is well-stocked with explosions, cars and women, and the production is extremely stylish. It does assume quite a lot of the viewer, in terms of remembering names, faces and circumstances from the preceding chapter, but as a direct sequel much of that can be forgiven. Solace's major flaw - and, as a Bond picture, this is utterly unforgivable - is that it routinely gets caught up in dull, blasé situations and lingers. A long stretch near the end of the second act nearly put me to sleep, and the plot never seems like it's too concerned about where it's going, nor does Bond himself. Several action scenes had potential (the flick is fully equipped with chases by land, sea and air) but the director is so head-over-heels for Bourne-styled handheld shots that he completely smothers us with them. Daniel Craig rarely gets the chance to shine in this chapter, his foil seems overmatched and insubstantial, and the big payoff at the end comes off as a cheap, hollow moral victory. Underwhelming all around, and completely lacking in the grins and winks that gave previous films in the series their character.
summary: Out of Touch and Generic, It's a Far Cry from the Casino

reviewText: 2008's "Quantum of Solace" is the second half of the story begun in 2007's "Casino Royale", part origin myth for James Bond (as played by Daniel Craig) and part revenge story for the death of Bond's lady love Vesper.  Like Casino Royale, this movie features a younger and grittier James Bond in a series of globe-trotting action sequences, and the beginnings of the ironic wit that is one of the signature of the Bond franchise."Quantum of Solace" picks up where "Casino Royale" left off, as Bond transports the mysterious Mr. White to MI-6 custody in Italy.  A nerve-wracking car chase that ends in a stone quarry sets the mood, followed by the discovery during an interupted interogation that Mr. White's shadowy parent organization has a long reach, even into the Secret Service.Bond, already in trouble with "M"(Judy Dench) for the way in which suspects keep ending up dead, sets off in pursuit of a Mr. Greene, whom he finds in Haiti making deals with disposed dictators.  He also finds a new ally, a lovely member of the Bolivian Secret Service.  When things go badly in Haiti, Bond is suspended and must rely on an old friend (Giancarlo Gianini in a priceless supporting role as Mathis from Casino Royale) to get to Mr. Greene in Bolivia.  Bolivia will be the scene of a short romance and a series of extended action sequences in the air, on the ground, and in an exotic desert hotel.  In a postscript to the movie, we meet a wiser and hardened Bond back in harness for "M.""Quantum of Solace" is a genuinely exciting action movie, and Daniel Craig looks a better fit as a maturing Bond.  However, the political overlays of the plot are trite, heavyhanded, and best ignored.  The theme music for "Quantum of Solace" may be the least memorable in the history of the franchise.  The action sequences are presented in a jarrng series of cuts that make them hard to follow.  This reviewer yearns for a little more dialogue and a little less brutality."Quantum of Solace" is highly recommended to James Bond fans as the next installment of the franchise, still cooking after all these years.
summary: The Second Half of the Story....

reviewText: There's a problem with the star system. Let me explain. I would easily give Casino Royale a B+ and Quantum of Solace a B- but I am obliged to give both films 4 stars. Quantum got off to an excellent start with the automobile chase. The organization is chasing after Bond with Mr. White in the trunk of the car. The connection to the first film is established with the delivery of Mr. White to British Intelligence. So far so good but then it kills Mr. White. It was a mistake. They should have spent more time on the development of Felix Leiter and Rene Mathis. Perhaps from a clue left by Mr. White during interogation Bond reaches Haiti it should have reached Haiti and Mr. Greene sooner. Instead Bond goes on some escapade with little to do with the story. With a better story line the film would have matched the success of the first film. Perhaps a better plan would have been to simply forget the first film and the opening with Mr. White and there would be no need to worry about the other film.

reviewText: I set my expectations low for this one given the rather mediocre reviews and that seemed to work out quite well because I enjoyed it very much. It certainly is not without its flaws. I found the action to be a rather excessive and felt like telling the movie to please calm down and take a deep breath. Casino Royale had been a step away from the over the top action of the Brosnan films but Quantum of Solace seemed to be sliding back to those mind numbing, high octane days. I also wasn't fond of the way much of the action was filmed with the rapid cuts and close up action that's so popular nowadays. It makes things very difficult to follow as everything becomes a blur. On the other hand Daniel Craig is much more believable as someone capable of fighting multiple trained fighters than Pierce Brosnan or Roger Moore.Quantum of Solace delivers on all the Bond requisites. We have beautiful locations, particularly a lengthy stay in Italy, gorgeous women and spectacular stunts. The gadgets are gone but I'm ok with that one. I also have to give credit to the producers for some great casting. There have been complaints about the movie plot and I have to admit that after a single viewing I'm not sure I completely get the villains scheme. Actually I have to give the writers credit for making the scheme mirror actual real word situations. It seemed to be a commentary on the way multinational companies manipulate countries for their own financial enrichment. I don't think I'm really revealing anything to say that Bond is now facing a new SPECTRE like enemy in the secret organization Quantum but rather than issue ransoms to the world Quantum uses a much more clever and insidious means to extract wealth. I did find it odd that the front company was an environmental group called Greene Planet. Is this a commentary on environmentalists?With this movie the future of the Daniel Craig years is taking shape. Clearly there will be a continuing storyline with Bond battling Quantum and presumably working his way up the food chain. Quantum of Solace picks up just minutes after the close of Casino Royale and unlike previous Bonds there are frequent mentions of the prior movie including several conversations about Vesper Lynd. Mathis and Felix Leiter have both returned played by the same actors from Casino. As much as I loved the old Bond movies it was always jolting that Leiter and Blofeld were always played by different actors often appearing completely different from one film to the next. My suspicion is that the new movies will be much more diligent about continuity and I find that pretty exciting.The excuse I've heard is that the script of Quantum of Solace was rushed to get it out before the writers strike which would explain why the movie is so action heavy and ran a scant 105 minutes. Hopefully the next movie in the series will get a more well crafted script and things can calm down a bit. I'm sure all the complaints from reviewers will be heard loud and clear at Sony. The movie is a step down from the previous effort but it's still better than any Brosnan movie besides Goldeneye. It's just that it gets compared to Royale which was so good. At least it never loses its dignity and stays classy throughout which is more than just about any other action movies being produced nowadays. Being the third best Bond movie in two or three decades is nothing to be ashamed

reviewText: This is going to be my shortest review EVER. Glad I came to QUANTUM OF SOLACE late...it gives time for this to have sunk in with fans.It has always been policy not to review Bond films but I can't help myself. This thing, while it had excellent action scenes (the 2nd star is for that), really stank. It made me long for Tim Dalton. Another reviewer said it all when he said this was one silly excuse after another as lead-ins to the action/chase scenes. For me, it didn't even accomplish that. Chase scenes and Bond cruising around the globe when he felt like it simply materialized from nothing.This thing has got to be the gelquel of the decade. The plotline is so stupid it almost works...but there is so little of it, WHO CARES? At the very end of the credits it says JAMES BOND WILL RETURN and I was praying by then that it won't happen. Just because this is supposed to be a re-telling of Bond from his "origins", well, that's not license to kill the damned thing as this film does.Daniel Craig is one of the worst actors in history. Pity because I like him. Give me some sort of Bond, but give me something. At least Dalton tried giving Bond some humanity, even if he departed further from Fleming. A video game has more emotional depth than this film, and equally compelling action/chase.
summary: Quantum of please give Daniel Craig a g.d. pink slip

reviewText: After seeing Casino Royale I couldn't wait to see Quantum of Solace.  However, the work schedule prevented me from seeing it in theatres, and the Blu-Ray price kept me from purchasing it until 'Black Friday'. Thank God I didn't pay full price for this awful movie.Craig is still good as Bond and so is Dench as M.  The story would have been passable if only you could watch the movie.  The cuts were so fast and frantic it was worse than reading Poe's the Tale Tell Heart.  The movie just raced past you and yet had the arrogance to think that as the Bond viewer it was your problem to keep up.Not.The look of the film is superb and you are relieved to see the Dench parts because the camera is allowed to sit on a tripod and be still.  The director of this film should have been given the boot after the first day's dailies and the producers who say that they take so much care must have taken a holiday and left the decision making up to people who thought that Michael Bay needed some competition.Unfortunate.  The silent action scene at the opera in the restaurant/kitchen was inspired however it was so confusing that you were left not caring.  The Bond girls were also uninteresting.  The 'tough' Bond girl was reduced to cowering in a corner after offing a bad guy.  Hard to believe? Well, like a lot of this non-viewing Bond experience, who cares.When the next Bond film comes out I'll wait for the dollar show, and I certainly will wait before I lay down money for a 'new' Bond (Craig) Blu Ray.

reviewText: "Quantum of Solace" was a Bond movie in the traditional mould, but with a twist; gestures to social conscience.As a Bond movie, it was good, but not likely to be mentioned in the same breath asThe Man With The Golden Gun,Die Another Day, or evenCasino Royale (2-Disc Widescreen Edition).  Bond follows a series of leads to a previously unknown organization, and collaborates with a beautiful lady who has infiltrated the organization to pursue her own agenda.  Chases in cars, motorcycles, planes, and boats, gunfights, explosions, the usual, but executed to a high standard.The twist; a lot more of footage clearly intended to portray the uglier side of the third world rather than the glamorous locations featured in earlier Bond flicks.  Consistent with this theme, references were made to sleazier dealings by Bond's bosses and allies, along with a human scaled villain who was building a cabal to inflict suffering (for a profit) on the prolitariat rather than the bourgousie.I'm sure much will be made of this attempt to place a social message in a Bond movie along side the usual product placement for Omega and Aston Martin.  It didn't do much for me.  If anything, it was slightly distracting from an otherwise passable story and excellent action.I liked it, but didn't love it.E.M. Van Court

reviewText: Once again, Daniel Craig gives a masterful performance as bond. By this film, the Bond character has become very dark, but Craig's performance is subtle enough to human exude some human emotion at the right time. Furthermore, the new "bond girl," Olga Kurylenko as Camille, is probably one of the strongest bond girls in the series.My main concern with this film is the plot. First, unlike most other Bond films, it is a direct sequel to the previous film ("Casino Royale"). I hadn't realized this and had not watched Royale since it came out, so I did not understand some of the references in this film. Some Royale references (such as Vesper, Bond's love interest) were obvious enough to pick up, but it was only after reading the reviews online that I realized the secret organization in this film, the Quantum, was the direct offshoot of the criminal network in Royale.Second, "Quantum" had too much action and too little substantive plot, even for a Bond film. The villain's plot (to obtain a monopoly on water in Bolivia) isn't particularly memorable compared to the plots of past Bond films. There weren't any particularly memorable or classic scenes in the film (such as the poker game in "Royale"). Ultimately, while the plot itself isn't horrible, and the acting and action scenes are good, the film overall is simply forgettable and doesn't leave me salivating for the next one.

reviewText: Bond (Daniel Craig) is back and bent on vengeance.  He is seeking to find the one who killed his beloved Vesper (Eva Green from `Casino Royale').  His path of revenge leads him to some familiar faces, a new femme fatale named Camille (Olga Kurylenko) and above all, a new villain, Dominic Greene (Mathieu Amalric), an environmentalist with a not so environmentally friendly hidden agenda.If you thought 2006's "Casino Royale" gave us a tougher Bond that packed one hell of a punch, "Quantum of Solace" will deliver a haymaker that will knock you out of your seat.  Within the first five minutes of the film you know that the action will be virtually non stop.  Almost any conceivable vehicle was used to film a chase scene.  Car, boat, plane, segway...well maybe not segway, but you get the point.  "Quantum of Solace" aims to entertain with adrenaline fueled action scenes, which it succeeds in doing.It seems as though the new generation of Bond is all about toughness, and shoot first and gather information later.  The high tech gadgetry of previous Bond films is ancient history.  So is the "Bond, James Bond" line that fans of 007 have come to expect in every film.  However, it is a refreshing change to get away from the gadgets.  It makes it seem more realistic, although some of the action scenes weren't.  The formula for a classic Bond film has been given new ingredients and has been shaken and stirred to give us the newer action packed 007 we get today."Quantum of Solace" is a sequel (the first film in the franchise to be titled so) and it will be a successful one.  Action fans will thoroughly enjoy this one.  Bond fans may nitpick at the missing ingredients, but nonetheless should see it because if you're a diehard fan then it's a must to see the latest installment of 007.

reviewText: We were introduced to a seasoned, machco, womanizing, wise cracking British Secret Agent 007 through the fabulous Sean Connery.  Surrounded by a cast of supporting characters; M, Q, Moneypenny and Felix Leiter and lots of gadgets.  We never got an indepth relationship or background character information.  Just good special effects, action and stories.  And of course the arch evil enemy organization, S.P.E.C.T.R.E..40 plus years later 20 movies and 5 James Bond's we start again, fresh, a new beginning of 007's career.  Casino Royale, James Bond's 1st 007 assignment without extreme gadgets but great character development and a fantastic story, a new James Bond (aka Daniel Craig, awesome!) This was a ground breaking movie to re-establish 007 into our lives.  A new original and deep (OUTSTANDING PLOT) storytelling experience.A first also was "Quantum of Solace" a sequel or Part 2 of "Casino Royale" a continuation of Bond's in depth character.  Plus closure, finale to many loose ends.  Brilliant!!!!!  AND we now have a new evil organization, "QUANTUM" (GREAT VILLANS).  "M" is the only returning supporting character.  Judi Dench is wonderful as Bond's boss.  Dedicated "M" and Bond having a stormy relationship through "Quantum".This Blu-ray installment captures all the action, visuals and sound that is expected of HDTV or HD Home Theatre now better than the movie theaters.Quantum begins / continues where Casino ends!!  All key characters return and their destinies are determined in Quantum.  Daniel Craig's James Bond has a more human, compassionate dedication to "Her Majesty's Secret Service".  We get to witness how 007's character develop and personal relationships are deeper and more satisfying.  The storyline is very detailed and sophisticated.  Dialogue is complex and important information is quietly and effectively used to move the story along.  A weaving of the grandest style.Believe you me this new James Bond is awesome.  More more action and special effects and edge of seat events.  Such gratifying conclusion to this 2 parter.Give this James Bond (Daniel Craig) a chance he is brilliant!!!Special Features are many and behind the scenes data is quite informative!!!This is a MUST HAVE Bond movie!!!!  Enjoy.
summary: Not since Sean Connery introduced us to JAMES BOND has he been so ELECTROFYING !!!  (explained)

reviewText: I enjoyed this film - as I've enjoyed nearly all Bond films that I've seen.  But the weakness of Quantum of Solace is epitomized by the way that the excellence of the supporting cast overshadows the main characters.  The incomparable Judi Dench makes a strong impression as M, and Mathieu Almaric as Greene was far more interesting than Daniel Craig's flat Bond - all special effects and grim efficiency without the soul, humor, and class that distinguish the great Bonds.  Craig's favorite Bond, Sean Connery, set the bar very high for his successors.  But I blame the screenplay and the director for the disappointing result.  The fast action sequence at the beginning was enjoyable, even though it was hard to follow, and it was even difficult to distinguish Bond from the mole he pursued.  The aerial scenes were unintentionally funny because they strained credibility past the breaking point: I had to recall the time I saw the Spiderman musical and the Green Gobelin got stuck in the air high above the audience, due to a mechanical failure.  Too much for Bond.  The real problem was that the screenplay didn't provide enough material for Bond to show sufficient depth, complexity, and charm.  Olga Kurylenko was beautiful without being very sexy, and the relationship between her and Bond seemed too much like a promising date that went nowhere; while the one night stand with the girl in Bolivia happened too fast without sufficient motivation - even for a one night stand.  I kept thinking how much Craig resembles Vladimir Putin.  APutin biopic might inspire this talented actor more than this mediocre screenplay.
summary: Mediocre screenplay with a few great actors

reviewText: To me, Quantum of Solace was a complete and utter letdown ! I saw and liked its direct predecessor Casino Royale, so my expectations were high. But I found some parts of QoS to be almost unwatchable. Did the editor go mad or was he doped up when he cut this movie? The action sequences comprise of extremely short, blurry images that pass with machinegun-speed. They produce an almost stroboscopic effect that literally hurts your eyes and numbs your mind and leaves you unsure of what's happened. At home, you can rewind the DVD player to watch it again. In the movie theater, you're hopefully lost. The result is a physically exhausting film experience after a mere five minutes of play. I almost switched the DVD-player off there and then. I know that the pace of (action) movies has picked up considerably since the nineties, and in general that is a good thing. But the pace of the action sequences of QoS is ridiculous and an insult to moviegoers. My young adult children (18 and 16) complained about this too, so thankfully I am not alone in this respect. Just lately, I began to fear that I have trouble coping with the increasing pace of today's movies because I have turned middle-age. Clearly this is not the case, then ! The action and violence in QoS is gritty and realistic, almost clinical. And I love Daniel Craig as the new JB. Five stars for him. But QoS the movie seems to have no discernible plot and what little plot there is is enigmatic (not in the positive sense), vague, illogical and lacks coherence. This quickly becomes annoying to the extreme. You never have an idea what's going to happen next and --most important--why. I am very happy with "the new JB" as portrayed by Daniel Craig, but QoS is definitely not the way forward with the JB-franchise.

reviewText: I've been a Bond fan since Dr. No was released in 1963.  I've seen each Bond film more times than I can possibly count.  I found this film to be a mid-level Bond at best, a big disappointment since the triumph of "Casino Royale."Simply put, each scene is a way to push the film forward to the next action scene.  And the action scenes are simply not that good.  The pre-credits sequence is an an extremely confusing car chase that doesn't come close to so many of the other great car chases in the series.  The theme song is possibly the worst in the series, it makes Madonna's "Die Another Day" sound good.  And the action scenes that come after are okay at best: a not very exciting boat chase, a CGI-enhanced airplane scene that looked like something out of "12 O'Clock High," etc.  The concluding action sequence, a fight between Bond and the villain in a burning hotel that catches fire way too easily is okay but unmemorable.Daniel Craig is very good and tough, (hes terrific in "Defiance" by the way,) but at times I miss the class and sophistication of the Connery and Moore films.  Olga Kuryenko, who was stunning in "Hitman," is absolutely gorgeous, but simply not used enough in this film.I don't want to criticise this film too much, it is still entertaining and the hour and 45 minutes go fast.  However it is not a great Bond film like "Casino Royale" or many of the others. However it is a James Bond film and the James Bond films are in a class by themselves.  It is probably better than Brosnan's last Bond "Die Another Day" and perhaps "The World Is Not Enough" and a couple of Moore's films like "Golden Gun" or "View to a Kill" and the Connery abomination "Never Say Never Again."  But thats about it.
summary: I've been a Bond fan since the beginning but.....

reviewText: When I first saw this film at the theaters, I wasn't particularly impressed. It was in watching it as a rerun along with Casino Royale that it came into its own. As other reviewers have pointed out, this film finishes up Casino Royale and refers to its effects all through the film. This is a more cerebral Bond and handles killing in a different manner than one at first realizes. All the actors are subdued and overly serious, apparently directed this way. And it works. We understand the killing aspect of a man who kills for his country, but also for himself in seeking vendetta, but also seeking to balance good vs. evil. The bad guys here seem low key and not really evil enough according to some reviewers. This is not true. It is the subtlety of their overt threat, which carries this charismatic response we can only define as pure evil. We have the cars, the chases, the stunts, the shooting, the girls and the maniacal bad guys seeking world takeover...all pure Bond! I suppose what is present in this particular serial is...perfect balance! And that's why this really IS a superior Bond. Re-watch Casino again and then Solace and the screenplay and storyline will merge. All in all...a very satisfying submission!

reviewText: This is one of those movies you're not sure what to think of until some time passes from your first viewing. I believe the main reason that this series has been going for so long is that, when the producers have made a mistake on one of their films, they will show an open mind, come back the next time around and fix it. EX.: the sillier space sagas YOU ONLY LIVE TWICE and MOONRAKER were followed respectively by ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE and FOR YOUR EYES ONLY, films in which Bond was brought back to earth; the outlandish DIE ANOTHER DIE was followed by the solid CASINO ROYALE and so forth. With this in mind, my suggestions for fixing the goofs on QUANTUM OF SOLACE are as follows:1) Hire a real, renowned great singer, not one teens will dig (as far as I know, Shirley Bassey is still alive and these kids can't hold a candle to her).2) Never again use the Bourne editing process, nobody likes it, period. You can't appreciate a great stunt when it cuts too fast to a next one which you don't end up appreciating either. QOS' editing all but itself sank it.3) The gun barrel scene goes at the beginning, never again at the end. What the heck was the point in doing so ?4) Go to any exotic countries you may like but use their most beautiful locales, not their ugliest. It's nice to find locations with "flavor", not so good when they don't "taste" so good.5) If you want the audience to hate the villain, don't just imply he killed a beloved characters as in the case of Mathis and Agent Fields. Show it on screen so we can detest him properly and thus enjoy his doom.6) When Bond kills the main villain show it. Don't just have him discuss it with his boss.7) As bad as things might be for Bond on the movie. Give him a few scenes in which he might actually be happy. One of his main characteristics is his enjoyment of the good things in life (drink, food, girls and so on).8) A follow up to 7: Bond must never say goodbye to the movie's main woman character in a car, in the dessert shaking hands or whatever. A body of water and heavy kissing have always been the norm (and worked out great as far as I can remember).9) Take under consideration: hotels in the dessert are not flammable per se.10) Bring back Moneypenny and Q. Their scenes always brought a smile to my face. Samantha Bond is more than adequate as the first but good luck finding someone to replace the beloved Desmond Llewlyn (but you have to do it anyway !).11) Make sure the villain's plot is something more evil and dangerous to world wide peace than simply leaving about a dozen people with funny looking hats, waterless.12) Also remember, there are great film-makers, auteurs and directors who know how to make great Bond movies. Which have been the best of the recent ones ? : GOLDENYE and CASINO ROYALE. What do both of them have in common ?. Need I go on ? I'm sure you can afford the guy.By the way, QOS is OK. Had a sane editor cut it it would be above average for Bond, as it was it turned out below the median line. I guess you can say it is not as good as the sum of its parts and as such a wasted opportunity.
summary: Good movie but not Bondian enough

reviewText: Commanding Hard Edged Bond FilmQUANTUM OF SOLACE is a superior hard-edged James Bond film. Daniel Craig commands the screen with his strong visual presence and captivating aplomb as Ian Fleming's dedicated civil servant. Craig's interpretation of Ian Fleming's James Bond is that of man of few words, but whose mind never sleeps, ultimately to get the job done. He is a physically fit, brutally effective thinking man's Bond. He has a certain unfathomable charm and sardonic humor that makes him appealing to the opposite sex on screen and to the audience as well. The plot of QUANTUM OF SOLACE is a bit thin, but then again, this film is really more of a study of James Bond and his world. This is very evident in Bond's scenes with René Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini) and then again with his scene with Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright). The tone of QUANTUM OF SOLACE is very dark and realistic. It is not a glamorous film as has been a hallmark of the series. It is a personal film. David Arnold's score once again continues to break new ground into Bond's hard-edged world. Arnold's "What's Keeping You Awake" is a very reflective piece and "Field Trip" is a real throwback to the classic Bond sound created by John Barry. I was glad to see that an actual Ian Fleming title was used for this film. I think this was rather fitting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: So they hired two guys affiliated with the Bourne series to help with this film. But if it's James Bourne-y, it's in a bad way - the idiotic, stupid shaking-camera style that makes the action unintelligible, even car chases and boat chases. Bond's escape from an elevator is a prime example of this terrible filming style. Something happened in there, but what? These shakey camera fools must be stopped!It's somewhat unfair, though, to complain - as some critics (and on-screen characters) have - about his killing too many people vs. taking them alive - in many cases, he's left no choice. It's kill or be killed in many pretty stressful situations.The hand-to-hand action is sparse but better than in the other Bonds - something more lethal-looking than the comical fisticuffs we usually see (though Brosnan's swordfight was fun). I mean, Bond should have had some martial arts training, right? Still, the Bourne idiots ruin the action with their wild camera movements.I didn't enjoy it as much as Royale, but it is a character piece - somewhat confusing, though. Has he come to terms with Vesper? Yes and no, it seems. The "field burial" scene of a fellow agent is also confusing. The film brings on what looks like tender moments, then seems to discard them as brutally as Bond casually discards various objects on-screen. And it looks like he uses a fellow-agent as a bullet shield in one instance, though I can't be sure. Cold. But I like this brooding Bond.On the other hand, we get a glimpse of his loyalty and perhaps affection for M, and how he sees her - a surrogate mother.Also, interestingly, Bond has to make do with various clunky forms of transport; it's his enemies that have the shiny boats and aircraft. In keeping with the reboot, he gets dirty and bleeds quite a bit.The theme song was widely panned by critics, but I found that it grows on you (well, it grew on me) and I now sometimes enjoy just viewing the opening sequence, which is very well designed and choreographed. The lyrics are well done, too. And, of course, I love the harmony line they've added for the Bond theme fanfare.Is Dominic Greene supposed to look like Al Gore? I don't know, although he kind of does. But he makes a poor man's villain, in a climax that is underwhelming. However, perhaps the Gore connection is significant - like Greene, his "save the earth" hypocrisy is despicable. Although all the "science" in his film has now been debunked - it cannot be shown in the UK without a disclaimer to that effect - Gore stands to make millions for his business partners and himself if his demands for alternate energy are met, while he is content to continue guzzling 20 times the normal person's energy ration. (google "al gore carbon footprint" to get an idea.) Rations are for little people.The worldview presented - talking and plot points - is somewhat naive and simpleminded. Case in point - the CIA is playing ball with brutal dictators for ... oil, what else? There's also a message about how our intelligence services should only deal with "good guys" - the mistake the Clinton administration made which led to a dearth of on-the-ground intel. But as M's superior points out, what are they supposed to do? Let the bad guys get all the oil? (The Brits should know; it was the superiority of their oil-burning ships - Churchill's hard-won cause - that let them sink the German navy.) More naivete: The locations are meant to contrast between the "evil and rich" West and the poor, victimized rest of the world. Never mind that their misery is usually the result of their own dictatorships.There's something in there about global warming, thankfully brief (perhaps purposely so, since most scientists now know the earth has been *cooling* for the past few years, and the latest IPCC admission shows that only perhaps 5 *actual* scientists - not 2,500 - agreed with its conclusion that any warming is man-made). In this movie hybrid cars abound, even in Haiti. But, hey, it's all movie make-believe, so take it with a drop of oil and enjoy it.
summary: Generally enjoyable, except for the super-stupid shakey Bourne camera

reviewText: Producer says, "Lets make a movie." Writer says, "But we don't have a story." Producer says, "Who, cares. I need some money so just toss together all the time worn scenes of old action movies."Proof in order (tell me if these are familiar): car chase; foot chase; fight next to ringing church bell; fall through sky light; fight on scaffolding; swing from ropes; grab gun at last second and shoot bad guy with unrealistic shot; boat chase; two airplanes in middle of nowhere desert ready to fly; unrealistic airplane chase scene in canyons; two people - one chute - jump at last moment from plane and with just 3 seconds of chute deployment at 135 mph happen to land in the only deep crevice in the desert; pretty girls in cars always show up at right moment; girl wants to kill bad people who killed her parents; bad people want to control resources; bad people are a secret organization; secret agent is suspect; finally, jump from burning building.Now the real negatives: To make all the above seem a little different they used a lot of quickly changing and nauseating camera angles which totally fragments the story. Actors who can only memorize one line at a time which adds to the fragmented incoherence of the story. A supposedly high tech touch screen which is old school to my iTouch.
summary: Tell Me if You've Seen This Before
Title: N/A

reviewText: Bond on the run...it sounds like a mid-sixties spy spoof, yet this is the new darker Bond being chased by the good guys as he tries to even the score left  unsettled inCasino Royale [Blu-ray].The secret of the Bond films has always been found in the Bond girls and the  chase. Here the girls take a break while James goes rogue and even M can't bring him in from the cold. But the chase, through parts of the world never seen in the series, offers spectacular action and awe-inspiring scenery.While the bad guys seek world domination as usual, this time they are cleverly disguised as green entrepreneurs and hailed by friend and foe alike. It is one man (Bond, James Bond) against their evil alliance and for once we feel as if one man, even one as resourceful as Bond may not be enough.There are moments in the movie which was largely shot in the badlands of Bolivia where we feel Butch and Sundance may emerge to help 007, but in the end no other cultural icons are required. Bond does it all, as he always has.Blu-ray was meant for movies like this. The action shots are cleverly staged and since in good Blu-ray the action seems to take place on inches away, real and involuntary fright is a frequent reaction.Danial Craig, now clearly the best Bond in twenty years, refuses to ham it up. He is a man of purpose, a man of action, and a man in the middle, uncomfortably caught between vulnerability and omnipotence. Where the plot sputters Craig commands our attention. and in Quantum of Solace, he desrves it.

reviewText: Nobody I know gets really excited about Bond films nowadays. Quantum of Solace is like most bond films: technically very good, halfway decent plot, decent acting and a slm-bang ending. This film meets all the expected Bond film requirements.I like Daniel Craig - he is a very good actor that brings a level of maturity to the role. The clever title (read: "Small Comfort") refers to Bond's quest to avenge the death of his lover in the first film. He's after the people who gave the orders, not just the people directly responsible. This leads him to bust up a scheme by an Illuminati-esque group of businessmen to control a major natural resource.There is alot to like about this film, the cinematography is great, there are some interesting action sequences and car chases. But where are the gadgets? No car gadgets, no watch/lighter/gun gadgets. There is one tricked-out phone in the movie, but it is not that spectacular; I guess the producerrs are moving away from that Bond movie staple.Quantum of Solace is a pretty good film, better than most, but there is nothing really special about it.

reviewText: This may not be up there with CASINO ROYALE and SKYFALL but for me is a good Bond in todays world of corporate control of the planets natural resourses. Marc Forster has made the shortest running time Bond but has put a lot of complex technical work in the film. It is basically a raw, visceral action film on land, water, air and fire.The film deals in todays politics where corporations are willing to deal with the Left or Right as long as they get their interests. The West is prepared to tolerate corporations in removing Governments who refuse to give corporations their cut. Daniel Craig for me is the definitive Bond. He seems like a real spy where previous Bonds relied on silly cartoon action and writing. Craig is a complicated Bond and in SKYFALL admitted to using homosexuality in achieving his goals for God and Country. I doubt previous Bonds would have accepted the ploy of homosexuality in their missions.My only problem with QUANTUM OF SOLACE was not enough satisfying expostion on the Quantum organisation and Mr White was the only dubious villian to get away. Will Mr White be seen in the next 2 SKYFALL sequels? Like I said this is a lesser Bond to Craigs other Bonds but is better the most earlier Bonds.

reviewText: I dunno. To me, this movie is worth around three stars, maybe three and a half...This isn't exactly what I'm jones-ing for when I tune in to a James Bond adventure. In re-imagining a grittier and darker franchise, with its stories placed strictly in real-world situations (no wild shootouts in outer space here), and in an effort to portray a leaner and meaner James Bond, QUANTUM OF SOLACE (and what's up with that inscrutable title?) again eschews some of the franchise's classic elements, the stuff which sets 007 apart from the other globe-trotting spies. There may be ramped-up action set pieces in this one, but the overall bleakness of the lead character depresses the hell out of you. Where did that sense of fun go?Okay, if you're gonna branch out into a different direction, then you better tell a whopping good story. QUANTUM OF SOLACE, 22nd in the string of James Bond pictures, doesn't. In this one, Bond uncovers a nebulous organization which has managed to ensconce its agents in those elite circles deeply influential on the world stage. As things play out, a takeover plot surfaces, involving the monopolizing of Bolivia's water supply, and this Bond must avert, even if it means going rogue.The movie follows up on the preceding (and superior) filmCasino Royale (2-Disc Widescreen Edition), which featured the death of James Bond's traitorous lady love, Vesper Lynd. Turns out that Bond is taking her passing real hard, and finding it a struggle to balance his mission with his thirst for get-back. He ends up partners with a beautiful Bolivian operative who bears her own internal (and external) scars. As Bond interviews people and as they begin to die in his vicinity, M, the no-nonsense MI6 matriarch, begins to question his dedication and true motivations.No doubt, the era of the blonde and dour James Bond got off to a rip-roaring start with CASINO ROYALE. But the franchise takes a step back with QUANTUM OF SOLACE. It doesn't bode well that the opening car chase is so lame and lackluster, with the director woefully piggybacking on those trademark Jason Bourne quick-cut, herky-jerky edits. And, taking a page from BOURNE ULTIMATUM, there's also a breakneck rooftop sequence. Daniel Craig can act, but the overwhelming thing he's got going for him is his physicality. His is the most physical and burly 007 since Sean Connery and George Lazenby drew salaries from Her Majesty's Secret Service, and surely a marked contrast from Pierce Brosnan's unimpressive frame. Craig's action sequences suggest a more intense, more brutal brand of violence. But a dichotomy rears up. The impression with CASINO ROYALE is that Bond is new to his license-to-kill status. But, in this movie, a direct continuation from CASINO ROYALE, he comes off more as a jaded, well experienced agent.In this leaning towards real-world based plotlines, there aren't many theatrical villains. The bad guys we end up with here tend to be very unremarkable sorts, although Mathieu Amalric isn't half bad as the sinister tycoon. The film does stick with its trademark two hotties rule, but halfway discarded are those tittilating names bestowed on the femme fatale with cheeky panache. The two women gracing this screen are lovely but nondescript types, with the main actress Olga Kurylenko touting the uninspired moniker of Camille Montes. Gemma Arterton, who gets secondary status, fares better, insisting that she be referred to solely by her surname. It's not until the end credits roll around that we find out her full name, which merits a rueful smile.We're all clued in, by now, that James Bond is damaged goods. But previous actors's takes on 007 were punctuated with a certain lighthearted touch (excepting the somber Timothy Dalton). I was on board with CASINO ROYALE's stripping Bond back to basics. But, in forsaking the glibness, QUANTUM OF SOLACE goes too far the other way. Daniel Craig's incarnation is striking in his moroseness, and in his utter lack of humor (and, yes, given, his girl had just died). There's this air of hopelessness about him. Add to that his single-minded, almost soulless devotion to his task at hand, and it adds up to a largely unempathetic character. As a nod to contemporary times, beginning with Pierce Brosnan's run, the characters in the film have been referencing Bond's misogynistic bend, his callous manipulation of not only women but of his friends. And, with the absence of whimsy and of that humor most often embodied in a wrily delivered catchphrase, there's not much to redeem his character or blunt that hard edge. As it is, this Bond is reduced to being a cold-hearted and unsympathetic killer, which is his core, anyway. Might as well put a skull design on his chest and have him start scribbling into war journals, know what I mean? Or maybe that's too harsh.CIA's Felix Leiter is here, as is Bond's beloved Aston Martin. Judi Dench remains a hard-bitten but comforting constant. There's even a callback to a classic scene inGoldfinger. But, frankly, I miss Q and his whizbang gadgetry, and also Miss Moneypenny. I miss the vodka martini and the "Bond. James Bond." And I miss that nicely turned double entendre. The James Bond franchise endures, but there's not much solace found in this film.
summary: Alternative film titles: Quiznos is Flawless. Xena is Lawless. Christmas in Hollis. Quakers Are Braless.

reviewText: Though only 1 hr and 47 minutes lone and the shortest and grittiest and least attractive of the Bond films, I think this was probably the one that I have watched more than the rest of them.  I love the grit, the dirt, the ugly surroundings, the asexual relationship between Olga Kurylenko and Daniel Craig who each has their own agenda and can well handle their situation alone, if necessary.  This is the first time that Bond doesn't get to sleep with beautiful lead.  Have you ever noticed how many of the Bond girls get bumped off right after sleeping with him?  Let's face it, the guy Bond is after isn't the worst villain in a Bond film and comes to an ironic end, but the villain Kurylenko is after is one of the nastiest, genocidal maniac in charge that has been in a Bond film.  Of course he is only in the film towards the end, however, Kurylenko's back story is more heartbreaking than Bond's.  This film is more Noir than the rest and the beginning action sequence in the midst of a construction site is actually kind of mind blowing for a film that forgoes all of the chases and fights that are in most Bond films.  I left the film satisfied and felt that all my questions were answered.  Usually I don't feel that way about a Bond film.  I had to watch "Skyfall" which is excellent several times before I got it.  The beautiful Bond girl in this film comes to an end all to suddenly and I keep asking myself, why does the villain kill her?  It just didn't make sense.  Finally, I realize, that it was because the villain cannot accept failure of any kind, even when someone has performed credibly and brought about a successful conclusion to an operation.
summary: This is the greatest of the 3 Craig films.

reviewText: Daniel  Craig's sophomore outing as 007 is a big quantum of disappointment.  After the stellar achievement of "Casino Royale", and keeping us breathlessly waiting for two years to see what Bond would concoct as revenge for the death of his beloved Vesper, scriptwriters Paul Haggis, Neil Purvis & Robert Wade along with director Marc Forster offload this stinkbomb of mediocrity on an unsuspecting public.  Forget the action sequences, set pieces, locations or babes--the only thing truly spectacular about this installment is just how far it fails to live up to its predecessor.  If the 2  hour "Casino Royale" felt like at least two movies in one, this one, at a scant 106 minutes feels like less than half a movie.  With little exposition, character development, motivation or dialogue, there is barely anything constituting a script--one wonders why it took three guys to put together what is essentially a collection of explosions and overly cutesy title cards.  The requisite array of foreign locations is present, but almost without exception they lack any sort of visual appeal.  Never has so much money been spent to so little pleasing effect.Daniel Craig is not provided with much of an opportunity to display his nuanced acting chops this time around,  but he proves himself a committed and fearless performer even with lackluster material and one of the most impressive human specimens on the planet.  He once again dons the impeccably tailored tuxedo (this time Tom Ford rather than Brioni), and inhabits a penguin suit like no one else, even when (perhaps especially when) covered in blood.  A breathless and destructive car chase down a twisty Italian mountainside opens the film, followed by a stunning sequence reminiscent of scenes from `The Bourne Ultimatum' and `Lara Croft Tomb Raider' as well as `Casino Royale' all in one as Bond chases a traitorous MI6 agent around a construction site at an empty house, demolishing everything in the process.  It all goes downhill from there, hobbled by a villian so weak and pointless he makes Mads Mikkelsen's Le Chiffre look positively Shakespearean, and the two most forgettable Bond girls ever.  English model Gemma Altherton as MI6 agent Fields is pretty in an insipid way but has a voice like Minnie Mouse and is so tangential to the plot that Bond beds her without even getting her first name.  This may qualify her for the "Easiest Bond Girl Ever" award.  Seeing as Vesper has been dead for all of a week, this is cold even by his standards.  Ukrainian model Olga Kurelynko has more screen time as Camille, a mysterious girl of intederminate heritage who has a vendetta dovetailing with Bond's, and she is very lovely, though inexplicably styled to look like Sophia Loren circa Houseboat.  After the incomparable Eva Green as Vesper Lynd we may as well get used to the fact that all of her successors will inevitably suffer by comparison.  Even so, these two achieve zero chemistry with Craig, even when he is half-dressed.  The only chemistry comes courtesy of Craig's scenes with Judi Dench's ascerbic M.  The next film could consist entirely of a three martini lunch between Bond and M. and we would watch, mesmerized.  What a shame they didn't make that film this time.

reviewText: "Quantum of solace" focuses around a real problem in the recent future. The crisis of the water in Bolivia is just an orange alarm around the rest of the world (I think to myself that we will exception witnesses in a very recent future about the creation of the OWEC(Organization of water exporting countries)).But the rest of the film as you and me may expect is made of amazing chases: by the sea, aerial, and car. However, a frantic camera that never stops from start to finish, is not able to support the numerous fissures through the film.Bond lacks that glamour taste: the luxuriant landscapes, the unerring casinos and the alluring women. We will miss the new futuristic devices in the vehicle of Bond. It's to say, there has been a thoughtful process of deconstruction and designed reengineering around the expensive caprices of his majesty's agent and the new paradigms in order to dissolve the touch of class and acknowledged elegance of the previous sagas.The risk is yours.
summary: Deconstruction of a legend and innovation of a modern myth!

reviewText: Tricky to rate a Bond movie for all the opinions out there for what a Bond movie should be. Ever since CASINO ROYALE (the DANIEL CRAIG version), I've been interested in the New James Bond as I like to call him. I fully understand the loyalty by fans to all of the previous 007 outings. However since the restructuring of the franchise in 2006, I find the character traits given to Craig's secret agent are way more compelling than the tired old 'who's the best Bond?'. This review is (as all of my reviews are) based solely on my outlook of a biased cinematical viewpoint. That viewpoint is this; all Bonds before Craig are somewhat the same.Purists scoff.Fans sneer.S'okay.Say what you will, but I've never, in any previous BOND flick, FELT Bond's motivation until the last 3/4 of CASINO ROYALE. QUANTUM is no different. Only when Craig's 007 says that there was nothing emotional betwixt Vespa and himself to M when this film kicks off, you realise how much there was for HIM with Vespa. He blames himself for her death. Giving Craig's Bond a dimension only merely mentioned in previous BOND outings. They have re-invented this character, people, Q ain't showing up.The action in this movie is relentless. The stunts are excellent. In the first half hour there are four sequences worthy of climactic battle in most big screen pics. There is very little story, however the machine that QUANTUM is, it's not needed. I thought the action was well lensed and intense. JASON BORNE is not as cool, nor filmed with the ferocity, as Craig's Bond by a long shot. As far as I'm concerned, Craig IS Bond. All memory has been wiped of what were decent, if cheesy, movies.This is different. This is new. And I love it.It would be easy to watch CASINO and QUANTUM back to back. They flow right together. The continuation is another plus to Bond's new feel.QUANATUM OF SOLACE is a necessary installment of the new Bond. Wrapping up a story line in the series and paving the way for many interesting new adventures, Bond truly finds, at the finale of the film, a quantum of solace.

reviewText: Quite frankly this movie was a dismal follow-up to Casino Royale. I loved the story driven Royale but Quantum was two hours of shiny objects and pointless characters. The bond girls looked and acted like teenage girls trying to be tough guys. What on earth was the point of the redhead who "was an office worker" being sent to bring Bond in? He's a "Double O" and they send the gopher from the secretary pool to pick him up in a kinky Eskimo-hooker-boot and raincoat outfit? Good move. I guess if we followed that logic in real life we'd send girl scouts after Bin-Laden. Throw the cookies at him girls! Get him! Get him! I do have to admit, however, that Craig and Dench really work well together and their scenes together are spectacular. Aside from that this movie really didn't even seem to try. Maybe because people complained about the long run time for Royale they chopped this one up into tiny bite-sized action shots and shortened it by cutting out all the quieter moments that give us time to breathe and reflect on why that last action scene was necessary while giving us a scene with actual acting and dialogue. Keep the longer run time and give us more intrigue and less explosions. And a less annoying opening montage would be better too.I have read reviews where some have said that the theme song for Quantum was wonderful because of the two vocalists involved. I hope you realize how flimsy that is. Even Beethoven did some second rate work. I thought that the entire opening sequence from song to visuals was a sad throwback to what made some (just some, not all)of the old bond films laughable in the first place. What is the point of a reboot for a series if you are going to repeat the mistakes of the past? I loved the visuals and music for Royale as they took the old theme and blended it together with some very interesting ideas. Quantum's opener features naked women gadding about to music that seems to have been created by recording two cats being smacked together.As a closing note I would like to say that this movie, despite comparisons to the contrary, did not remind me of the Bourne films in the slightest. At least those movies kept a thread of dignity and actual plot mixed in with the hectic "Shakey-Cam" action sequences and car chases. What I wouldn't give for a genuine spy film these days.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of 007. Daniel Craig is right up there at the top as my favorite actors to portray Bond. Quantum is a lot of fun and is an excellent movie. Why a 4 star rather than a 5 star? I consider this to be the least of Craig's efforts in the role of Bond, and I want there to be some room to distinguish Casino Royale and Skyfall. But overall, this is a great watch and a lot of fun.

reviewText: I'll give it this: the Blu-Ray presentation of this film is beautiful to look at and listen to. But the movie itself? I'm having a problem with the last couple Bond flicks: with each subsequent movie, they become more and more difficult to understand or make sense of. This one left me completely in the dark. By the end of this film, I still didn't understand who the bad guy was or what he had done, or why, I couldn't make heads or tails of the bad guy's ultimate goal, who was working for who, or why anything was happening at all.  I think in trying to make a thinking-man's action movie, the Bond franchise has gone over the top and now makes movies that it takes a phd in quantum physics to understand.  I'm done.  No more bond.
summary: They get more and more confusing with each new film.

reviewText: James Bond, unfortunately, becomes an invincible spy again.He beats up bunch of agents in an elevator with his hands tied behind his back. He can outrun, outdrive, and outpunch anyone. Oh, and he hardly ever takes a punch from anyone. His pistol never misses or runs out of ammunition while the machine gun fire of his enemies always miss. Did I mention Bond can probably bench 800 pounds in this film? (he lifts one man up with ONE arm).Yet, this film is still better than most Bond films. Daniel Craig is still a great actor and his portrayal of Bond is unmistakably the best.The hotel in the last sequence, which seems to be made of a cardboard, has multitude of methane tanks conveniently located where Bond can blow them. Furthermore, the hotel apparently had zero fire suppression since the entire hotel catches fire in mere 5 seconds. But the hotel must be made of smoke free materials since there is ZERO smoke in midst of all the fire. How convenient for the movie crew!This movie is nowhere near as good as Casino Royale. Why go back to the old "invincible Bond" formula that has been done and redone so many times?
summary: Why go back to the old formula?

reviewText: The problem with QoS is that the villain is about as threatening as a Care Bear, and rather than getting his hands on nuclear missiles, he's attempting to corner 60% of the Bolivian water market. This would be weak enough if it affected somewhere in the US, but Bolivia? In an issue that would barely raise an eyebrow at the UN, Britain obviously decides to send its number one spy to fix the problem.In between a chain of over-the-top action sequences there's an InstantMix plot of no consequence. The plot points are TV-grade: in one 'pivotal' scene, Bond overhears the villain's master plans while hiding behind a fence. This is as much for the audience's benefit as for Bond's, in case we missed the over-signaled evil plan while being confused about the movie's title. Out-Bonded by True Lies and mercilessly parodied in Austin Powers, I think Bond's time may be over. It's really a shame since Casino Royale wasn't a good reboot of the franchise.

reviewText: Quantum of Solace, the long awaited sequel toCasino Royale (2-Disc Full Screen Edition)(2006) has finally arrived and continues immediatly from where Casino Royale ended.We join James Bond (Daniel Craig) in a fast car chase already in progress. Bullets and car metal flying everywhere. With the car battered without a drivers door, he makes it to his destination to meet M (Judi Dench). He had Mr. White (Jesper Christensen) in the trunk of the car the whole time. M (Judi Dench) instructs Bond and then they attempt to get information out of Mr. White. They come to realize that there is a new enemy organization, "Quantum", and as Mr. White tells them, "they are everywhere".Bond soon finds that out and is on another foot chase in Italy on the roof tops and in a bell tower. Along the way, he meets Camille (Olga Kurylenko) who offers him a ride.Bond goes on a trail to find this new villain. He enlists the help of Rene Mathis (Giancarlo Giannini) to go with him. However, didn't we the audience, after watching Casino Royale (2006), come to realize that Mathis can't really be trusted?At the airport, Bond meets Agent Fields (Gemma Arterton) who will help him on this night in more ways than one.Our CIA agent hero, Felix Leiter (Jeffrey Wright) is already hot on the trail from his end who is already in a private plane meeting with the villain Dominic Greene (Mathieu Amalric) with his henchman, Elvis (Anatole Taubman) and others. Felix is being asked by Greene to kill James Bond. He tells them he doesn't know him.Rene Mathis mentions they are invited to a party. It is there that Bond meets his enemy Dominic Greene (Mathieu Amalric) and his lady friend, Camille.James Bond's CIA friend, Felix, is already there.When Greene attempts to make Camille fall in the water below Fields and Bond come to the rescue. Bond makes a getaway with Camille.But what about Agent Fields?We also discover another villain, General Medrano (Joaquin Cosio).Bond ends up killing some people along the way and after he kills an agent at a performance of "Tosca", M cannot trust him and must decommission him.  Bond continues his hunt.Producer Michael G. Wilson makes his cameo appearance as a man sitting in a chair in the Haitian Hotel lobby.Right away you will notice this film has a different look. The traditional gun-barrel scene is gone, but turns up at the end of the film. Such a stupid move. Also gone are the traditioal phrases, "Bond...James Bond" and "Shaken...not stirred".Most of the scenes are filmed on location, but in dirty, grittier, run-down looking places. Nothing exotic here.The rumored nudity of Daniel Craig never appeared and the love scene cut very short.When Director Marc Forster really wanted this film to be cut short to 106 minutes, he meant it making it the shortest Jame Bond Movie ever.I enjoyed the performaces of Joaquin Cosio who I hope to see more of in the movies. I think he could have made a memorable villain if he where in the lead.Gemma Arterton as "Agent Fields" certainly raised my eyebrow. Such an interesting character, but all too short-lived.Jeffrey Wright was given much more to do in this film as "Felix" and I hope we will see him in action again in the next James Bond films.Producers Michael G. Wilson and Barbara Broccoli have mentioned that they really want to change James Bond and that with the upcoming "Bond 23", they want to make further changes.Nothing is familar in a James Bond film anymore as they take away the traditions.They are practically circumcising the James Bond character and look of the films.Well I do miss the tuxedo middle-aged James Bond with the interesting gadgets and his traditional phrases and his flirting with Miss Moneypenny and quipping at Q.With every movie the MI6 headquarters and M's office looks different.I also miss the wonderful opening sequences they use to have with a brilliant song."Another Way to Die" sung by Jack White and Alicia Keys is the worst song I have ever heard in Bond movie history. This one is rock and rap.I did like composer David Arnold's music score within the film and "Crawl, End Crawl" by Four Tet, written by David Arnold, played at the end credits, is a nice tune.Quantum of Solace won't be remembered as one of the best. It only makes us yearn for the Bond films of the past. I still thinkGoldfinger (Special Edition)(1964),Octopussy(1983),Licence To Kill (Special Edition)(1989) andGoldenEye(1995) are quite entertaining.Quantum of Solace had shades of Goldfinger (1964),Never Say Never Again [Blu-ray], Licence To Kill (1989) and a non-Bond filmThe Godfather Part III - The Coppola Restoration(1990) in it.TheQuantum of Solace (Two-Disc Special Edition)(Widescreen) contains:Disc One includes: The Feature Presentation, "Another Way To Die" music video, Theatrical Teaser Trailer #1, Theatrical Trailer #2.At your option, the movie can play in English, Spanish, or French.Disc Two: Special Features:Bond on Location (24 min.),Start of Shooting ( 2 min. 54 sec.),On Location (3 min.),Olga Kurylenko and the Boat Chase (2 min.),Director Marc Forster (2 min.45 sec.),The Music (2 min. 37 sec.),Crew Files.You may also choose English or Spanish subtitles or none at all.No audio commentary, no deleted scenes.Update: Daniel Craig and Judi Dench will return for Bond 23 to be released November 9, 2012.
summary: James Bond finds his Quantum of Solace.

reviewText: When Casino Royale (2006) came out, I thought it was the best James Bond film I'd ever seen with Daniel Craig easily (in my opinion) the best Bond in the franchise history (yes, even better than Connery). So, needless to say I was really looking forward to Quantum of Solace. Unfortunately, like a lot of people I was underwhelmed at best.Don't get me wrong, this film has arguably the best filmed action scenes this side of 'Dark Knight' as well as some very creative moments in the best of Bond fashion (one particular involves Bond with a camera inside a new-age opera house).Daniel Craig and Judy Dench are still fantastic in their roles, but where this film seemed to fall short was giving you a reason to care about them. Bond always seems to come off cold and crude (though does have a few amusing one-liners), and M seems to be changing her mind a few times too many regarding her best agent. The other characters are a bit too unimportant or underused to really feel a "bond" with them ( I liked the return of Mathes but he TOO left the screen a bit too early). I'm not even going to comment on the villian.The film's plot ranges from dry to needlessly complex but I realize you don't see a Bond film for the story. I did like how it did bring closure to the events from Casino Royale at the end, so in that and the incredibly well staged action scenes the film is still worth seeing at least once. I just wish this movie had more going for it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Movie:After loving the heck out of Casino Royale, it was pretty much assured that I was going to see the inevitable and sequel but I was not prepared for what I saw. This was not the Bond I wanted to see after CR.It all starts off with one of the worst car chase action scenes I've ever seen. Thanks to the shooting style, it's incoherent and annoying to watch. The movie tries so hard to be a new Bourne-style spy romp mixed with some very bad elements of older Bond movies; such as globetrotting around the world on the most convenient pretexts. CR put Bond in his own, more realistic but not real, world. This movie tries too hard to place him in the real world and be Bourne and it fails miserably. It's pretty long and mostly boring. The action also tries too hard to be Bourne, extensively utilizing poorly-done shaky cam. My girlfriend and I did not enjoy this and one of my friends began slamming his head on his knees after about 30 mins.Blu-ray:Picture and audio are excellent. Barely much to mention in the bonus features department. It's very safe to expect a double dip when the next bond movie hits theaters.

reviewText: Starting out with a heart-pounding car chase scene through the mountains on impossibly narrow roads with more two-way traffic than DC at rush hour, albeit with fewer guns, there is no mistaking where this movie is heading.  Bond (Craig) machine gun sprays the bad guy without blinking an eye.A few scenes later there's a foot-chase scene, with jumps off balconies, dives through windows, and tap-dancing on poorly manufactured tile roofing.  A high-wire trapeze fist-fight on an intricate system of scaffolding and pulleys ensues, where Bond and his nemesis display talents that could win an Olympic gold medal for gymnastics and cause vertigo at the same time.  Between yawning and checking his watch, Bond single shots the villain between the eyes.Up next we're introduced to the smoking hot Camille (Olga Kurylenko), and then there is another epic car-chase scene.  Camille drives a little buggy, perfect for the narrow European streets.  Bond follows on a dirt bike he just stole.  BAM!  Straight into an unbelievable boat chase scene, where Bond uses a bad guy's melon as a ramp, and causes more water deaths than the Titanic.Oh, don't forget Bond can fly a plane!  Some schmuck lets him "borrow" the plane, wherein Bond takes machine gun fire from a jet and a helicopter while Camille flails around in the back like a rag doll, a gorgeous rag doll.WHEW!!  I was seriously waiting for aSegwaychase scene.  This is the ultimate chase scene movie.As for the movie, it has an interesting enough, somewhat implausible plot where the bad guys attempt to horde a resource by controlling assets in an undermining, illegal, and insidious manner.  It's up to Bond, Camille, a beautiful redhead babe who Bond beds, and the assorted cast of British spies who help Bond out along the way to stop the bad guys.A few of the classic elements and lines are missing, but since I'm not a huge Bond fan it wasn't too much of a letdown.  With that said, I highly recommend this intense flick for action fans, but hesitantly for hard core James Bond fans.
