reviewText: Marc Foster created a very nonsensical film that lacks narrative and direction. James Bond is simply not present in this film.  This robotic, and malfuctioning, killing machine that Daniel Craig portrays always does things without the slightest bit of regret or thought. He's respsonible for the death of two members of the british secret service. Bond's personal escapades gets Agents Fields killed, he  tosses a special branch agent off a roof, and kills suspects on a whim. What the hell is wrong with M ? Not only should this guy should NOT be a Double-O agent, he should be imprisioned for life. His motivations make no sense either. Why exactly did he rescue Camille, who tried to kill him moments earlier, that first time ?  How could he have possibly know she was in danger ? Why did he hand a random guy his phony business card ? How could he have known anything was going on at that opera house by simply glancing at bags on a table ? Also seducing Agent Fields was right down there with Steve Urkel seducing Laura Winslow in Family Matters. "I can't seem to find the stationery", please.Also in the vein of Licence To Kill it's a matter of not taking a breather just once to enjoy the woman, food, or drink. Hell the writers don't even give Bond enough time to put on his tuxedo. I am not saying you need one in every film but if your going to have one, give him a chance to get one ! He actually steals one at the opera house in a matter of secounds and amazingly, it fits.* That is just too much to buy. They try to shove in some of the old 007 charm pathetically with the clumsy Fields seduction, I reiterate, "I can't seem to find the stationery".I really could not care less about Greene's evil scheme of stealing water and lord do they try and make this seem important. Every once and a while the issue of Bolvia's water supply comes up from some random conversation and Greene simply states that water is the most precious resource and for no reason at all, Bolivia's Agua is the priority. There is also a painfully left wing slant in this film, "going after the oil is wrong !". I don't want to get into politics but all I am going to say is Felix Leiter and M, especially M, should really know better.Simply put this is a very poor Bond film. Dominique Greene is the most bland antagonist in the series' history, a stupid rap song for a main theme, the cut-a-secound and badly presented action pieces, and an un-charismatic Bond girl.* To further expose the idiocy of that scene, one doesn't need to look any further than the previous Bond outing. Bond complained to Vesper in Casino Royale how she couldn't replace his own dinner jacket properly without knowing his exact measurements.
summary: One of the very worst Bond films

reviewText: This meets all the criteria of a masterful adventure but it also has a conscience without rubbing it in our faces. About a year ago I read where Matt Damon liked his character from the Bourne series because he was not Bond.I agreed with that assessment.But with the newer attempt to make James Bond a contemporary MI6 player we're seeing something that has been avoided in the past and that is a human machine with a heart. He may not wear it on his sleeve but actions do speak louder than words. He's not a cold agent of vengeance (even as he sometimes looks and acts like one) but a man trying to make a difference as well as hold his own agency's feet to the fire. In his defiance Bond risks exposing the sad state of today's political realities but also acts to retain or recover some ideal worth defending. Like Jason Bourne he knows he's been someone's patsy but decides to spin that into a benefit.The bottom line; James Bond is trying to protect not only England, but the free world, from the greedy, jaded players and puppeteers who think the world and its people are up for grabs. In that, he's finally doing his job.Would Ian Flemming be proud? I can only hope he would be.I'm sorry for the lacking specificity to any actions and scenes. Suffice it to say, I want you to see it with a clear head and open eyes.One bit of advice: leave your nostalgia at the door.
summary: I'll be watching this for a long time

reviewText: Yes, Bond is not Superman or Spiderman or Batman.  He is a secret agent,a human being, so when I see him making totally impossible leaps just shy of leaping tall buildings in a single bound I know that the makers of this latest film are wrongly thinking more is more instead of realizing that less is more.  In the opening foot chase sequence of "Casino Royale" there was a fast, furious, high leaping foot chase - yet it was much more believable than the similar sequence in "Quantum."  I remember the train compartment fight between Sean Connery and Robert Shaw in "From Russia With Love" - and that battle in a contained space was a hundred times more exciting than all the over-the-top action in this current Bond outing.Having said that, Daniel Craig is a superb Bond.  "Casino Royale" knew how to balance its relatively more believable action sequences with quieter moments of character building.  In "Quantum" we have just too, too much action (most of it totally unbelievable and more suited for a superhero movie), often inaudible dialog, editing speed that makes much of what is going on or even being said too fast-paced and a plot that is totally impossible to follow unless you have seen "Casino."  The villain's motivations are quite absurd also, once we finally figure them out.The movie is still a worth-see because of those too-seldom subtler scenes where we see Craig's Bond more as a human being than as when he is playing Superman.  I hope the next Bond film is toned down a couple notches - and that the producers and director realize that action isn't everything, especially when it is insulting to the intelligence because NO one could survive most of the stuff that happens in this installment.Still worthwhile, even for Craig and Judi Dench alone.

reviewText: "Quantum of Solace" could have been more aptly titled "Quantum of Speed." The film is literally one chase scene after another. Of course, you have the inevitable car chase, but you also have boat and on foot.Storyline is surprisingly thin particularly since Paul Haggis (Crash, Due South) was the author, but the characterization within was excellent.  Essentially, Bond (Daniel Craig) is after an organization that no one even knew existed which has managed to penetrate MI-5 deep enough to have gotten one of their men placed as the venerable M's bodyguard.Bond, of course, has his own agenda.  He's also seeking vengeance for the death of girlfriend, Vesper.  The two missions segue together for him and often tend to have others wondering what he's really after.Naturally, people who come up against him die.  He's only defending himself, but it gets annoying when his superiors are trying to get information about this mystical group and their purpose.While I enjoyed "Quantum of Solace," I think it's regrettable that it's one of the first Bonds that doesn't stand alone.  It's too dependent on knowledge of "Casino Royale."One aspect of "Quantum" I really enjoyed was the exploration of the relationship between Bond and his boss, M. At one point, someone asks Bond if the woman is his mother.  "She thinks she is," is his answer."Casino Royale" marked the first Daniel Craig as James Bond film.  Craig's rougher demeanor and appearance was a return to more of what I read in the Ian Fleming novels, rather than the smoother persona that actors like Pierce Brosnan and Sean Connery portrayed. I miss the gadgets and not once did Craig say, "Bond, James Bond." But, it's a new day and as an action film junkie, I'm ready to roll with it--in cars, planes, busses, or even on foot.Rebecca Kyle, November 2008
summary: In a car, in a boat, on foot...

reviewText: I was really skeptical of Daniel Craig being able to pull off the role of James Bond. "Casino Royale" dashed my skepticism and convinced me that Craig IS Bond and the movie itself was, quite possibly, the "perfect" Bond film (maybe not the BEST, but a perfect Bond film nonetheless).Well, "Quantum" picks up approximately five to ten minutes immediately after "Casino" and moves forward at a break-neck speed. The action sequences are very well done (although I did have a slight problem with the rapid editing - it proved to be a little too much and a little distracting) and the fight scenes are just about some of the most realistic and exciting as I've seen. Craig delivers a top-notch performance as the not-quite-so-debonaire (but he's getting there) and stoic "double-oh" agent. We are beginning to see his character evolve from a near-brutish thug he portrayed in "Casino" into a more suave and slightly more sophisticated agent.My biggest problem with "Quantum" is the story. To sum up, I found the plot to be a bit too simplistic and the enemy organization which supposedly had people everywhere isn't quite as intimidating or forboding as you would expect. Regardless, this is a logical direct sequel (the first ever in the Bond franhcise) to "Casino" and still delivers a satisfying film that should please MOST Bond fans or, at least, fans of the genre.It's a GOOD film, it's just not great like 2006's Casino Royale. To be fair, I would actually rate this movie at 3 and a half stars. And on a side note, "Quantum" gets my vote for having the WORST main title theme in the history of the Bond movies. I'm not particularly a Jack White fan, but I expected so much more from Alicia Keys. TERRIBLE song and easily forgettable.I purchased the single disk edition which really has no interesting bonus features to speak of, but the picture and sound quality were excellent.Recommended, but only if you're a Bond fan or a fan of espionage/action films.

reviewText: When CASINO ROYALE came out a couple of years back, everyone called it a "reboot" of the Bond franchise.  And in many ways, it was.  The campy elements that had long been a part of the series were gone.  The over-the-top gadgetry was far less in evidence  (partially because REAL gadgets are pretty amazing these days).  The bad guys were not constructing gigantic underground lairs to house their nuclear weapons...they operated in ways that seemed just a little more within the realm of reality.  The action sequences used all the tricks that the BOURNE movies seemed to invent, so they felt more visceral and painful.And anchoring this new "reality" was a charismatic, almost minimalist performance by Daniel Craig...who looked like no other Bond we'd ever seen.  He cut an imposing figure, and for once, it was actually okay for Bond to get a little roughed-up looking (not TOO much, mind you, but a little).In short, CASINO ROYALE felt like something completely different in the world of Bond, yet enough was familiar keep it unmistakably Bond.  It gave the series (and the viewer) a surprising jolt of adrenalin.  We were at last seeing these movies with the same thrill of discovery that audiences for DR. NO felt when Sean Connery first ordered a martini.QUANTUM OF SOLACE does nothing to tamper with the new formula.  And thus, it must suffer some in comparison to CASINO ROYALE.  The tone is the same (perhaps even a little darker), the action sequences just as jarring, the bad guys just as seemingly mundane and Craig is the very compelling center of it all. (I remember really rooting for Clive Owen to get the Bond franchise...but in reality, I'm quite happy with Craig.)The plot has something to do with water rights in Bolivia...oh, who cares!  Has anyone ever really invested themselves emotionally in the plot of a Bond film?  What we want is to see astonishingly lavish locales (here we get Sienna, Italy, Port au Prince, Haiti, Bolivia and more).  We want Bond to charm the ladies (nicely done, although Bond now sleeps with far fewer than before).  We want him to have a dry wit and toss off some clever one liners (still done, although far less winkingly than Moore & Brosnan did, thank goodness).  And we want GREAT ACTION SEQUENCES!And the sequences ARE great, and they come in ample supply.  Heck, the movie starts with a car chase that would be the climactic chase in many lesser films.  And when I say start, I mean START.  There is no set-up whatsoever.  Just BOOM...here you go with crashing fenders and flying metals.  Glass shattering and machine guns firing.  No easing into it.  This is followed by a nice, quiet scene that lasts 5 minutes and then BOOM, we're off on a rooftop chase through Siena.  It's all very good stuff, and I really enjoyed myself.  (Who would have thought a director like Marc Forster [Kite Runner, Finding Neverland, Monster's Ball] would have had such a movie in him?  Then again, who saw John Favreau kicking butt with IRON MAN?!)Craig is a more somber Bond, because you may remember he lost a loved one (who betrayed him) in the last film.  So now he's out for revenge.  So we see a little tiny bit of torment in him...not so much to detract from the fun, but again, in the manner of this "new" Bond, to make the film seem a little more human and down-to-earth.  In fact, the underlying theme of the film is conflict between doing what you know is right or safe and exacting revenge at any cost.  Yet I say again, who really cares?  It's nice to see the film isn't laughing at itself...but it also knows how to deliver on the action.Judi Dench continues to be a strong, maternal presence for Bond...I hope she continues to do these films forever.  Has there ever been a better M?  (Alas, there is no Q or Moneypenny!)  Jeffrey Wright turns up again as Bond's CIA friend Felix Leiter.  He's fine, but under-utilized.Virtual unknown actress Olga Kurylenko turns up as Camille, the "Bond girl" who is on her own quest for vengeance.  She cuts a striking, international figure...but I must admit she is pretty forgettable as well.  I don't see her going down in history as a memorable Bond girl.  Gemma Arterton fares better in the much smaller role as the "secondary Bond girl" Strawberry Fields...but she is not Diana Rigg or Ursula Andress either.  And the always enjoyable Giancarlo Giannini shows up in a small part.I liked the film quite a bit, as I hope you gather.  It fails to elevate the franchise to another level as its predecessor did...but then again, did we need that?  If you salivating for some good action...QUANTUM will fit the bill.  If you're in the mood for great acting and storytelling...surely you already know to steer clear of a Bond film!
summary: Not groundbreaking like CASINO ROYALE...but still packed with thrills.

reviewText: Quantum of Solace (Marc Forster, 2008)The more I see of films with which Paul Haggis was involved, the less impressed I am with Paul Haggis. And okay, I'll give Haggis Casino Royale, which was (and I freely admit to heresy with this) my favorite James Bond film to date. Daniel Craig makes a passable Bond, but it's not the actor, it's the light in which Bond is portrayed in this new incarnation; he's not a cartoon good guy like he was in all those old flicks, no matter who was portraying him. It's another of those cases of superheroes getting dark, dark, dark, and it fits (to me, anyway) right in with Ian Fleming's original vision in the novels much better than Connery, Moore, Brosnan, etc. (and lordy, let's not forget George Lazenby). Unfortunately, the main problem with Quantum of Solace is that it takes this new, improved film Bond and sticks him in a cartoon landscape. It's an interesting reversal, to be sure, but ultimately an annoying one.Daniel Craig returns as Bond, and for the second time, we get a much darker, more nuanced character than we have in previous Bond films. But everyone around him, no matter how good the actor, is a cardboard cutout. Mathieu Amalric, who brought so much to The Diving Bell and the Butterfly, makes a very fun villain. He would've been great when up against one of the previous Bonds, in a cartoon-meets-cartoon matchup of the sort that made movies like The Spy Who Loved Me and Moonraker so much fun. But this Bond demands characters who match him; if you've got a 3-D Bond, it makes little sense to put him up against 2-D villains. And Haggis and co. do seem to realize this, given the Bond girl, Olga Kurylenko (Max Payne); this is one of the few times the Bond girl has actually been a character instead of an accessory. Camille, Kurylenko's character, has motivations. She's acting, rather than reacting. (As a contrast, consider the jaw-dropping beauty Gemma Arterton, who plays the much more traditionally-Bond-girl Strawberry Fields.) But still, Camille is pure as the driven snow; she lacks the moral ambiguity of Bond's character. (And even Bond realizes this. "You've never killed before, have you?" he asks, ever so gently.) Perhaps there's only room for one fully-developed character in a Paul Haggis script. Let's face it, that's one more than there was in Crash.All that said, what everyone's been going on about re: Quantum of Solace has been the action scenes, and if you're an action scene junkie, then this movie is for you. As long as you can get through the middle third of the movie, anyway. (I spent said middle third wondering where I could see that incredibly cool version of Tosca, which I have since found out is available on DVD. Huzzah!) And the action scenes are, of course, pretty darned cool. Top of the line, in fact. As they should be, to try and mask (unsuccessfully) the fact that the plot gets lost a lot in this movie. Don't get me wrong, there is a plot, and with a bit of reflection when there's a lull in the action, you'll put the pieces together well enough, but it's too complex to get jammed into the shortest official Bond film ever made. (And perhaps that's the problem; as Casino Royale was the longest, maybe the screenwriters thought they'd have more time to explore some of the avenues that beg exploration here.)So, yeah: good action scenes, good main character, everything else falls flat. ***
summary: Tries to do way too much in too little space.

reviewText: This is Daniel Craig's second picture as James Bond and there are some carry-over characters from "Casino Royale" -- Mr. White (a bad guy) and Mathias (an old MI-6 agent) and Felix Leiter (CIA).It appears there's a new threat to world peace in the form of "Quantum" -- a secret organization that has infilrtated the highest levels of the world's governments, including British Intelligence.  This is an all action film.  Apparently, Bond has slowed down in his feminine conquests after Vesper's death in "Casino Royale" -- he beds the British Embassy woman who's to escort him out of Bolivia and she's later killed by Quantum -- but the heroine, Camille (Olga Kurylenko) relains chaste. Mathieu Amalric is Dominic Greene, an ecological master villian out to corner whole countries' water supplies.Eon Productions really went all out on the action and special effects.  This is a non-stop action film and Craig must've gotten more than his share of real cuts, scrapes, and bruises.  I give this 4 stars.  This film is best seen with its predecessor "Casino Royale" to help tie ends together.

reviewText: As a fan who followed Bond since his first incarnation (i.e. he was Connery), up to now I have always been disappointed with his follow-ons.  Moore was too corny, Dalton too glum, etc.  It seemed that the plots were more or less the same, all so tightly wrapped in formula that in a way the gadgets, girls, and special effects were all that mattered.  I grew indifferent to the films, though would see them in passing.  Now, with this new series, I am in awe of how they are both re-making the character and enlarging the themes.First, the films form a series, so it is still uncertain what is really going on.  There are clues, connections between the films, but the whole remains a mystery.  I find this absolutely and delightfully intriguing for the imagination, if one is so inclined to exercise it for fun.  All we know is that there is a shadowy international organization that has not only infiltrated MI6, but has ambitions that are truly global in scope, at once a web of conspiracy but also of geopolitical proportion.  Bond has been able to muck up their immediate schemes in both films, but it doesn't seem to have gotten them very far.  So, we await the next film, where more of it will come together from the seemingly significant incidents and re-appearing characters.  It is on a par with the Bourne films in my opinion.Second, Bond is a grittier, more emotional character, who is deeply wounded because of Vesper and hence on a personal quest, a mix of mission and vengence.  I could completely believe that he is tormented, even obsessed with the puzzle, and has no problem breaking the rules or risking disavowal.  Plus, there is a fabulous physicality to his acting - he gets injured, has limits to his strength, and hence is more realistically vulnerable.  Again, one thinks of Jason Bourne.It is so new and fresh - with superlative acting and an intricacy that fits with current filmmaking - that it surpasses Connery in certain ways.  Sure, I will always like Connery, but this territory has gotten me back as a very serious fan.  Bravo!
summary: continues to push Bond into new territories

reviewText: First off, let me say that with time, and changes in taste, the Bond movies I liked when I was younger are almost unwatchable.  Even one of the highest grossing Bond films, Die Another Day, wasn't that good.  The reason: Everything I used to like about Bond when I was a teenager/young adult.  The gadgets (invisible car, laser watches, "Q", space stations), the sexual ennuendos.  Listening to the lounge lizard routine now makes even Pierce Brosnan seem lame.  In short, I never really liked Bond movies as they always seemed a bit cheesy.  I guess it's kinda like 80's glam rock.  It might've been cool then, but this is a different world with higher expectations.Now, with Casino Royale and QoS, we have a believable Bond.  One that is not perfect.  One that has more than one "look", who never has all the answers.  I realize that this takes away what makes Bond Bond, but that's where the problem is.  There is a group of people who liked the old Bond movies, even those with Sean Connery and those that thought they were lame characters in unbelievably stupid situations.  Seriously, how many individuals think that, without an army, they can take over and maintain rule over the entire world?  Or better yet, try and milk countries for money?  How about killing off the main character with a hat or a laser?With QoS, we have a subtle Bond, one still conflicted over what happened to his love interest from the last movie ( a first, I believe for Bond movies).  I thought the story was very engaging.  A movie where the tech takes a backseat to plot.  It is a more complex plot than what you may be used to, but that's a good thing.  The opening car scene, the knife/scissor fight in the hotel, to name a few, and especially, the scene where he is facing the possibility that he will have to do the unthinkable to avoid a horrible fate (hint:  not this way).  I still get chills.I believe the director is trying to flesh out Bond so that the incarnations we're used to seeing are explained.  The fact that he didn't always make it when he was jumping from structure to structure is a basic example.  And this is the first time he slept with a woman, not to pump her for information, but just because he wanted to.I honestly liked the character development mixed in with my action scenes.  It may not be perfect, but I think the director and the Brocoli family are trying to do it right for once.  Give us motivation behind actions as well as some cool action scenes.  From what I rememeber, this had more fast paced action than CS.  I'm waiting for Bond 23 and looking forward to James moving on, focusing on his career and perfecting his free running skills.To the reader, this movie is a polarizer, you'll either like the direction it's taking or you won't.  Either way, you should watch the movie.By the way, my home theater is only a year old.  I had no problems with the sound field or picture.

reviewText: **1/2Those anticipating a smart, savvy follow-up to the superb, revivifying "Casino Royale" from 2006 will be sorely disappointed by "Quantum of Solace," an instantly forgettable entry in the ever-popular James Bond series.A muddled, barely coherent storyline - featuring a hitherto unknown group's involvement with some sort of badly explained eco-terrorism - is no match for the overwrought and overproduced nature of the film, in which Daniel Craig's 007 goes from being a complex, conflicted character in "Royale" to a soulless killing machine here.The action sequences are hectic as all-get-out, but with no one at the center of them for us to really care about or root for, they quickly loss their luster and impact.Here's hoping for better things from the franchise next time out.

reviewText: I give some weight to what professional movie reviewers say, but their yap that Daniel Craig is perhaps the best James Bond ever is so much hogwash. This new Bond is not handsome (indeed, he has the face of a brawling longshoreman), suave, or debonair.  He's utterly humorless.  Irony, cheeky responses, and any kind of word play are strangers to him.Admittedly, I haven't seen "Casino Royale," but given the critics' praise of this sequel it appears Craig is still in character.  And it's not much of a character.  Defenders of this new Grond, er, Bond, will say that his grimness is the whole point--he's out for revenge.  But all vengeance and no play make James a dull boy.Plus, he's a pig.  When his sort-of buddy is murdered (whom Bond convinced to go with him on a dangerous trip) Bond simply picks him up and dumps him into a trash bin.  Not to hide the body (which it doesn't), not to clean up the scene or keep the corpse from further damage, but for no apparent reason at all.  Maybe the show's producers just wanted to rattle our conception of the James Bond character, or drive home his maniacal lust for revenge, or some other witless reason.The show itself is reasonably well done and photographed, but most of the action scenes are made up of the oh-so-current quick cutting back and forth between antagonists.  The result makes the fights hard to follow and dizzying for the viewer, and the violence seem more fake than otherwise.If it's spy vs. spy type thrillers you like, I recommend any of the Bourne movies over this latest Bond series.  They're far superior in just about every aspect you can think of.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I did like Quantum Solace but this is a movie that seems to have very little to do with the fantasy James Bond.  Clearly the attempt has been to make 007 more real but the more real he becomes the less like James Bond  he is.  Imagine making a Batman Movie starring Bruce Wayne (James Bond) but eliminating Alfred (Moneypenny).  Getting rid of all of the Bat Gadgets (no Q gadgets) and eliminating all of the super villains like the Joker (no Goldfinger or Dr No).  Keeping Commissioner Gordon but placing him in a common role (M is part of the action).  Then taking all of those pneumatic women that characterize Bond films and making them into --- a babe.  This is what they have done to Bond - interesting and fun film but is it James Bond?This movie starts out with a car chase that has no beginning but seems to take forever.  The purpose of this chase seems to be to bring the culprit to M for questioning.  This merely becomes an attempted assassination of M , which results in a foot chase that also takes forever and right in the middle of the Sienna horse race.  This setting doesn't seem to have any relevance other than a great chance for the film crew to see this famous race.The bad guys here seem to represent some sort of a super secret organization that is fronting a nefarious business enterprise.  Of course they are thwarted but the super secret organization apparently marches on after Bond, the Agent Babe, and the bad guys totally destroy a luxury hotel built in the middle of nowhere.  How this hotel survives or why it is there is never clear.The film editing meets current standards which means that all action sequences have so many jump cuts that you can't follow the action and the close-ups are so close that you can see the weave of the clothes but not what they are wearing or doing.  Of course there is the requisite plethora of car crashes, car chases, property destruction, and killing innocent (nameless and unseen) people to satisfy contemporary tastes.  The plot is the classic plot where Snidely Whiiplash threatens Tess Trueheart and ties her to the railroad tracks.  But Dudley Doright arrives in the nick of time and rescues her - that sort of sums up the plot of Quantum Solace.  I do admit they didn't include the villain twirling his moustache and shouting "Curses Foiled Again" as he fades into the night.This is a fun film but just your run-of-the-mill action film that happens to have a hero named James Bond.  It's fun but not a 007 film.

reviewText: I grew up with James Bond movies. Various Bonds through the years were really just new faces on old formulae. I was upset when this most-recent reincarnation broke the mold with Casino Royale. No more corny innuendo, stiff editing and just-plain awful bantering dialogue. I initially missed the quips, puns and cardboard characters. Craig didn't fit my conceptiuon of this legendary series.The last Bond flick, and this one more-so, takes an attitude adjustment. Like, maturing. Quantum of Solace also took -for me - a few critical viewings to realize that although it's not the same spy comfort candy, it offers far more depth and excitement.The editing, particularly, is new; not just for the Bond franchise, but versus all other filmsof this new millennium. Far more intense and visceral, it hits on many more levels.The writing is far more mature and multi-leveled. Sometimes, demanding. It fits with allother production and creative aspects. Overall, this can be seen as a new or next-stepevolution of the action-intrigue-character-searching film genre. For me, five stars. Can'twait to see if the producers have the courage to continue pushing the cinema envelope.Do see the film several times. Not end-to-end necessarily. But look at the film critically.Alot will be revealed. depth, motivation and so much brilliant craftsmanship.

reviewText: Just to establish in everyone's mind that "Quantum of Solace" is a sequel to the highly-successful 007 reboot "Casino Royale," it picks up the action just minutes after the previous film left off.  That strategy seems to have backfired, however, causing viewers to unfavorably compare it to its predecessor.  Bond attempts to uncover the global conspiracy that was responsible for Vesper Lynd's suicide in "Royale."  It seems like that premise is innocuous enough... but it isn't.With the release of the third Daniel Craig Bond movie, everyone has piled manure on "Quantum."  Craig joined in, saying that "Quantum" "wasn't well-written."  One reviewer in a popular magazine sneered that "Quantum" "suffered from Jason Bourne p---- envy."  In fact, the lackluster response to "Quantum," along with MGM's collapse, led to a three year suspension of the franchise; there was some talk that there would never be another Bond film. Was "Quantum of Solace" that bad?  Other than the cat-with-its-tail-stuck-in-a-fan theme music, courtesy of Alicia Keys, No.The real problem with the film was that it dared to touch a wire that has generally been avoided in Bond films; relevance.  Though they're part of the spy genre, Bond films don't exist in the real world.  They are often adolescent male fantasies about state-funded luxury, beautiful willing women, fast cars and a free-ticket to kill.  In short, don't look for Le Carre plots here.  Sometimes, when the silliness becomes too much - like in a Roger Moore film or in "Die Another Day," the franchise dials back to grittiness.  But the filmmakers always carefully avoid making explicit political statements.  "Quantum" broke that rule: it used a "ripped from the headlines" plot about a major corporation stealing Bolivia's water supply, and it depicted the Quantum group as a corporate octupus that had infiltrated the world's governments.  It even depicted the ugly moral compromises the U.S. and U.K. were making when resource-hunting in the Third World.  The very use of the name "Quantum" may have been a dig at mega-financier George Soros, who has an international organization called "Quantum."This film is therefore not bad, but it rubs the money people the wrong way.  Moreover, whenever audiences sit down to enjoy escapist fare, only to see a depiction of real-world problems, they often make their displeasure known.  The Broccoli family - makers of the Bond films - were chastened, told never to make a "relevant" film again.  Duly humbled, they made the popular "Skyfall" three years later.  Hooray, and free lobotomies for all.

reviewText: Powerful action, hard Bond - where's the humor, the irony of past Bonds? Most of all, why isn't the 007 theme accompanying when Bond goes into action. In Casino Royale it came in at the end, when the familiar saying, "Bond, James Bond," rolled off of Craig's tongue. I felt, since he was really now 007, that was a precursor to the music returning to his action sequences. But, alas, it wasn't.When "Golden Eye" opened, fans crowded in to see "Remington Steel's" Pierce Brosnan become the new Bond, the theater audience actually cheered when he broke through the wall driving the tank, the Bond theme blasted away. Gone is the thrill.And the opening title, why is it at the end? Someone dropped the ball. As a lifelong Bond fan, I felt cheated. The music, the humor, it's gone. As far as I'm concerned, so is Bond. I have seen every bond movie, including Sean Connery's return in "Never say Never" and the spoof of "Casino Royale" featuring, among others, David Niven and numerous Bonds on DVD.I've added Daniel Craig's "Casino Royale" and "Quantum of Solace, but I think the franchise is over. It's just another Borne look alike, fantastic stunts, but neither entertaining as Borne nor the past Bond's.I miss the 007 formula.Sad.
summary: Quantum of Solace, not your entertaing 007

reviewText: These latest two James Bond films are really drifting away from what we expect from a 007 adventure.  This Daniel Craig is just way too serious and kinda dark and mysterious.  Perhaps that's how Ian Fleming wanted him to be, but in the past 40 years, we got use to more humor and some suave womanizing from James Bond.  It's really hard to care at all if this new James Bond fails a mission and dies.And another thing:  I think that they wanted to hurry up and get this film over with, too.  Even though it dragged, it still only ran about an hour and 40 minutes.  Most all the other James Bond films were at least two hours long or more.  For as short as this film was, it still seemed rather tiresome and endless.  Of course, it's hard for another actor to follow Pierce Brosnan because I'm sure many may agree that Pierce Brosnan was probably the second best James Bond in the industry.  Sean Connery being the ultimate best Bond. Roger Moore was pretty popular but I felt he was rather stiff and boorish.  He wasn't too impressive as a fighter, but all the Roger Moore Bond films had the best stories and the most interesting filming locations.  And, I'd even say that Timothy Dalton was a more screen-friendly favorite for a James Bond than this Daniel Craig is.  Now that I've seen this film, I don't think that I'd want to buy it.  In fact, I may just go ahead and get rid of my copy of "Casino Royale" too.  I'll just say that my James Bond library ends with "Die Another Day."
summary: I'm convinced now that I am done with seeing future James Bond films

reviewText: Lots of fighting, done in quick cuts that are hard to follow.  A Bond that fights, chases, and gets chased.  Good chemistry with M.  Marginal revenge plot.  Few gadgets.I want to point out one scene that I feel is representative of the "Classic Bond" versus the "New Bond".  The rogue James is 'caught' and steps onto an elevator with several other agents who are taking him into custody.  The doors close.  The next scene in the "Classic Bond" would be the doors opening, James straightening his tie, and as he walks out of elevator he would say some clever line and the camera would pan to show the other agents sprawled on the floor.The "New Bond" is shown in fast actions clips as he smacks the guys around, and then as he walks off the elevator he pushes one of the guys arms back into the elevator with his foot.  I felt a little cheated.I'll go see the next one, and I hope it is more like Casino than this one.
summary: Other Reviews are Dead On - This is so-so

reviewText: Quantum of Solace for me was a flipped around movie.  We start the film with a car chase and though it looked quite exciting, if you were not familiar with Casino Royale, it would make little sense.  Solace is a sequel and if you have not seen Casino, you won't follow the subtle anger of 007, his thirst for revenge.  We meet another Bond girl -- she is also more than she seems, and wants the blood of a man who brutally killed her family and burned her house when she was a little girl in Haiti.I must say the director of photography really knew his stuff.  The gorgeous Italian vistas, the amazing mountains and deserts of Bolivia, amazing.The script really needed some work.  The connection between M and Bond was not clear.  I'll have to watch it again to really understand their relationship in terms of trust and responsibility.  M says she does not trust him to his face but says something else to another agent.  The big evil organization we never get any closure on.  What happened for example to the Bolivian plot?  What happened with the men and women who apparently were connected to this organization, sitting in the opera house plotting and planning?  These questions are answered somewhat, but not in a clear manner, so they lose a star for this.Rewatch Casino Royale, and then watch this movie immediately after.  Solace does not stand on its own, and I think that's why the negative reviews.The DVD is very "plain vanilla".  A couple of theatrical trailers, a music video by Alicia Keys and that's about it.  Ho humm.Oh, when I said a flipped around movie:  The credits and the famous Bond theme are played at the END of the film, not the beginning.  Interesting but threw me a bit.Rental!  Waiting for a fresh, cleaner Bond in the next film.See:Casino Royale (2-Disc Widescreen Edition)
summary: Decent Entry into the Bond Mythos!

reviewText: Watching the Bond series reinvent itself with Daniel Craig as the titular British secret service agent is one of the great cinematic joys of the last decade.  James Bond has given me more guilty pleasures than I can think of since I watched my first Bond movie, "The Spy Who Loved Me," at the tender age of eight.  But I had to admit that the series had gotten flabby, bogged down in its own legends and traditions.  Not even the welcome addition of Pierce Brosnan - my then-second-favorite Bond after a young Sean Connery - could break the cycle.And then Daniel Craig took over as Bond with "Casino Royale," and happy days are here again.For us, that is, rather than Bond.  Craig's Bond suffers and is somewhat joyless. This works - the guy's a freaking assassin.  Craig radiates danger like no Bond before him - he's now my favorite guy at the helm because he's so darn believable.  I'm not sure how much mercury the filmmakers inject in Craig's eyes for these movies, but no Bond before has had as steely a glare as this man.In "Quantum of Solace," Bond glares.  A lot.  The movie opens minutes after "Casino Royale" closes - Bond is at war with the sinister criminal conspiracy - now known as Quantum - that took down his beloved Vesper at the end of the last movie.  The British secret service knows nothing about these characters, and Bond goes after them in a semi-official capacity.  Quantum is a scary organization, willing to kill at the rumor of disloyalty and with henchmen placed in the highest, most secret halls of power. Bond tracks these guys from Italy to Haiti to Bolivia as he tries to exact revenge while answering the most important question - did Vesper truly love him, or was she just using him?  Along the way Bond is aided by Bolivian secret service agent Camille (Olga Kurylenko), one of the best Bond Girls in years.I enjoy the Bond stories that have less to do with global domination ("Moonraker" comes to mind) - those plots are too outlandish, and how often does one guy get to save the world?  Just how many madmen are out there who want to take over the world?  Here, we watch a super-agent begin his war against a criminal conspiracy, and we relish the fight we see as much as the fight to come, as Quantum is alive and kicking at the end of this movie.My only quibble with this movie is its use of the currently-hip hyper-cutting technique during action scenes.  During the opening car chase, I almost lost my lunch, the cuts were so dizzying.  This is a tremendous action movie, but the filmmakers should have more discipline and allow a shot to play for more than half a second before cutting to the next shot.Here's looking forward to the next Bond movie with back-to-basics Craig - the best Bond we've ever seen.
summary: The spectacular reinvention of James Bond continues

reviewText: "Quantum of Solace" (2008) works better as a companion piece to "Casino Royale" rather than a traditional James Bond epic. The film plays like a fragmented novella, which accounts for its 105-minute length (the shortest 007 running time on record). Daniel Craig delivers another solid performance as a tortured, vengeful Bond - definitely the right man for the job. Judi Dench's M gets better with each installment and her chemistry with Craig packs a vital punch. In the low-key villain department, Mathieu Amalric's sociopathic portrayal is reminiscent of Klaus Maria Brandauer's Largo in "Never Say Never Again" (1983). Director Marc Forster keeps the thin narrative moving, but seems more comfortable with actors than bone-crunching action sequences. "Casino Royale" was a hard act to follow and the Bond producers should be credited for trying a different approach. Based on its own merits, "Quantum of Solace" remains a flawed yet strangely compelling 007 entry.

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I consider Sean Connery the best Bond, but among everyone else that has played this role Daniel Craig is in my mind a clear second. In this movie, Craig does a fine job, but I found the script a little bit of a mess. The action starts right after the end of Casino Royale, and we are thrown into the middle of an action packed sequence that is hard to follow. Not only because we don't really know what is going on, but also because the way in which the action scene is presented is too frenetic and it's hard to even see who is who in many instances and determine what is actually happening.I like action movies, but it annoys me when in an effort to make the action super high pace, the directors go over the top and we end up with meaningless sequences of events. Luckily for this film, once those initial moments pass, things get better. There is actually an interesting plot in place, with Bond suffering from the loss of  loved one and walking the thin line between going rogue and doing his job. As usual, there is suspense and intrigue, mixed with action and romance.This film is definitely not boring, but it is lacking some of those distinctive traits I have come to love in Bond movies, such as the off the cuff humor. Overall I was entertained, but it it not a Bond movie that will come to mind if someone has never watch a film with this character and asks me for advice on which one to try.
summary: Entertaining but not among my favorite Bond films

reviewText: Frankly, this film did not have good word of mouth as it came to me, but alas, Im a huge Bond fan, so I had to see it.  This movie starts where Royale left off, with Mr. White in tow, from the first scene onward I felt I was watching a Bourne film, I kept waiting for Craig to turn and be staring at Damon in the mirror, like some sort of lame Mission Impossible gag.  This is not a bad film, hardly Casino Royale, but better than the Bronsan yawners, it just seemed so kinetic and honestly, as times I had a hard time understand what the hellz they were saying.  Matheiu is a HORRIBLE villain, he looks like Roman Palanski crossed with a toad, he has no presence AT ALL, it's like with Casino Royale and that zero that bled from the eye, I mean, what the f?, is this all they can come up with?  The reason behind the villians motives is just the limit, I mean, WATER? and dont get me started on the bizarre title, I realize it's a metaphor for Bond and Vesper, but still, it's a mouthfull.  All and all, fast paced, nicely acted(love Dench), but really lots of noise signifying nothing, really im already forgetting this movie, uh what's the title again?

reviewText: When I first saw this movie in the theater I was less experienced, hadn't seen Casino Royale in years, and didn't really "get it".  Now, many years later I've grown in understanding and also have very recently seen Casino Royale.  My opinion of the film is practically the opposite of my first impression.*Mild Spoilers ahead*The Illuminati theme to the organization Mr. Greene is with originally felt like a huge cliche, the action was so good it seemed cliche, and that's all I could tell was in the movie.  Now upon revisiting, I see a truck load of character depth I never saw the first time, impressively real-looking action (even though I know it's over the top, it's very well done), and an enemy group who is still larger than life, but only by a margin of reality.Excellent movie, looking forward to Skyfall, and don't let the negative reviews turn you away if you can relate to my review even a little.

reviewText: Perhaps it's a little fitting that MGM went belly-up recently as their most important property is clearly being treated like so much rubbish.A long time ago...on an island far far away...existed a series of movies about a Secret Agent named James Bond. They were intelligent, exciting and quite ethereal experiences for all of us old enough to remember the theater back in the day when Hollywood still produced heroes.Somehow, the formula was able to subsume and highlight all that was good about being a heroic man - yes, the Alpha Male was still loved and cared for, particularly if he spoke English properly. Political fascists were clearly the enemy, whether they were Nazis, Communists or 3rd world dictators. The Bond women were unknowns and mind blowingly beautiful, classy and dignified. And more often than not, it was the velvet and translucent voice of Shirley Bassey that would once again welcome us to this world where a man's dreams were real.While Sean Connery was Bond, Moore brought a slick, sly and witty sensibility that also worked. And so the mythos was established. Real men wore plaid, drank martinis and kindly softened the blow of death by sending the bad guys to their end with intelligent sarcasm.Then somewhere along the line, political correctness, nihilism, anti-Americanism, man-hatred, anti-capitalism, anti-British(ism?) mixed with a mindless worship of...mindlessness (violence and otherwise), took hold. It turned our world and economies into a faint echo of their former selves. And it turned this franchise from what young men aspired to be...to a long running joke of a videogame without a controller or stop button. And oh yes, the movie posters suck too.Quantum of Solace is likely the greatest culmination of all of this senseless idiocy that bears a shade of a spec of a remembrance, to what Ian Fleming and the Brocolis created.Daniel Craig, Pierce Brosnan could have both been masterful Bonds. Brosnan demonstrated that when he actually played James Bond in The Thomas Crown Affair. Instead, the suspension of disbelief in flushed down the toilet and we end up with storylines where the evil-Western-Corporation-Media-Monster is once again going to get us all. Oh yes. Nike is the enemy. Sadly, they don't check us at the airport looking for American media terrorists or Running Shoe operatives but who cares about the truth when you can sell people bs that they are hungry to buy.Maybe I'm wrong, but nothing would make me happier than seeing Daniel Craig light up a cigarette - a real one - drive while drinking a martini, smack a girls ass and kill one of those nasty middle eastern terrorists that would like to blow all of us up for having the audacity to state that 2 plus 2 is still bloody 4.Something is wrong with a world where you can't say "terrorist" on the BBC for fear of offending the um... terrorist. And something is even more wrong with a James Bond that dances on the strings of mental infants that don't need, believe or understand the heroic spirit of man.I await you James Bond, to return to us. Perhaps Sony will buy you up lock stock and barrel. The Japanese aren't scared of heroes. Never have been. What the hell happened to the rest of us?In the meantime, check out Sandbaggers and Callan, both on DVD.

reviewText: James Bond (Daniel Craig) is seeking revenge for the death of his lover Vesper Lynd, and is also after an organisation called "Quantum" that no one knew existed - and stopping the environmentallist Dominic Greene (Mathieu Almaric) from taking control of a poor country's supply of it's "most precious resource"...Not as good as the superb Casino Royale - I might even say a disappointment - but I still enjoyed it! Daniel Craig is excellent in it, his Bond has his own agenda and is out for revenge - and there are some impressive stunts, fights and chases, and bursts of pretty strong violence. It's certainly exciting to watch.However, I felt the plot and story didnt have as much focus as the previous film, and Mr. Greene isnt nearly as good a villain as Le Chiffre in Casino Royale - IMO he didnt seem dangerous enough and there wasnt much motivation to go after him.I did like how the relationship between Bond and his boss M (Judi Dench) unfolds - at one point M gets so annoyed with him she cuts off his credit cards.Also, it occurs to you as you watch Bond chase (like in the superb opening car chase or rooftop free running) or beat people up, you're not really introduced to these people - hence you don't know them or reallly CARE what Bond is doing as much. Also the camera moved so fast it was sometimes hard to see what was going on.You understood why he felt how he did - "trust no one" though as he was very hurt by his lover's death.I loved Olga Kurylenko who was gorgeous as Camille, she was a great character on the same level as Vesper, as she was sexy and strong but also had emotional depth. However, British actress Gemma Arterton (Strawberry Fields? Oh for the love of...) was a waste as a Bond girl and really isnt given much to do - but in one of her scenes there's a neat reference to an earlier Bond classic, see if you can spot it!The lack of gadgets, stupid quips and sex is refreshing however, and I liked how it picked up where Casino Royale left off (to all intents and purposes, this film is really a continuation, and in that sense a departure for the Bond franchise).You will get more from this film if you have seen Casino Royale before though.I realise I may have sounded negative sometimes during this critique - in my view it is nearly a 4 star movie but I think the reason why I appear disappointed is because I had very high expectations. It was still a good, entertaining film and I will buy it on DVD.
summary: Not quite as good as Casino Royale but solid and exciting

reviewText: MGM went all out when it came to picture and sound quality, as both are very good and excellent, respectively. Every Blu-ray title should treat its movie like this!The exotic and rundown locations were photographed well, and all the shine and the grime come across on this disc. The sound quality actually eclipses the video quality with a lossless audio soundtrack that gets you right in the action and then backs off to let you enjoy the Italian coastline, only to hit you again when the action returns. Well done!When it comes to deciding whether a release is a purchase candidate or a rental, it comes down to how often I plan to watch the movie and what extra features exist on the disc that would extend my enjoyment of the movie.Repeat viewings will depend upon your opinion of the movie. I really liked Casino Royale, and Quantum of Solace is an acceptable sequel, but not up to the same level as its predecessor. While I wouldn't mind watching the movie again if guests were interested, I don't see myself sitting down to watch it again for quite a while.So that brings us to the extras. I'm glad to see two trailers for the movie, in HD and in 5.1 sound. Too many Blu-ray releases omit trailers or present them in stereo only (or shove them into the BD-Live features with limited video and sound quality). The rest of the extras aren't all that interesting, and there isn't a commentary or deleted scene to be found.This disc also forgoes anything resembling advanced content. No picture-in-picture commentary, no BD-Live functionality. Basically, the extras are high definition versions of what you would expect to see on a DVD release.Is this disc worth purchasing? That's up to you and priority you place on these aspects. The movie is treated well. If you're a fan and your expectations stop at just the movie, you're set! If you want something more, my guess is we'll see a double-dip special edition in about 18 months or so.
summary: Excellent sound and very good picture quality, not many substantial extras

reviewText: This is the worst Bond film I've ever seen.  That said, the institution of such brings high expectations.  Opening with an incredibly weak action sequence, the film segués from one action scene to the next with dialogue and context jammed awkwardly between.  The pace was rushed.  The chemistry between characters was pushed or simply not given time to develop in intimate scenes.  Such sandwiching of detail resulted in the constant spewing of information in dialogue.  Conversations didn't seem natural they were so laden with detail needed to advance the plot.  Even Bond's trademark steamy sex scene was cropped of sensuality or intrigue.  The witty humor of Bond, himself, was absent.  The soundtrack was one of the few consistent points of interest.  Had this film been stripped of the franchise and made under a different context it could have stood with some touch-up.  As a Bond film it was awful.
summary: You only got one shot, make it count

reviewText: The 2nd installment of the 'new-and-improved' Bond franchise, starring Blond Bond Daniel Craig, is a satisfying action movie with a disjointed, and mostly irrelevant, central narrative about forgiveness and redemption.Be warned, Quantum picks up the threads where Casino left off and continually refers to plot points or characters from the previous film in an off-hand way. If you haven't seen the first film then deciphering the story line is a lost cause.If you have seen Casino you'll probably be lost a good portion of the time anyway given how briskly the story moves along. Details are thrown at you almost tangentially, new characters are introduced and killed before you have time to remember their faces or names, and Bond skips across the globe like a groupie tagging along with a band on a World Tour.Fortunately, none of this really matters. The brutal hand-to-hand violence and gritty car chases a la Bourne series are still intact. Craig makes it clear that his take on the impulsive, introspective Bond is here to stay. The dialogue is nothing special, but it's mature and free of cheesy one-liners. In other words, the updates to the franchise made it into the sequel.Casino Royale is required viewing, and is also the superior film, but Quantum is an enjoyable and fast-paced action film that re-affirms the direction the franchise is heading in.
summary: A Quantum of Solace: A Modicum of Plot - A Plethora of Action

reviewText: `Quantum of Solace' is pretty much your typical James Bond film. Bad guy has fiendish plot to control a world resource, Bond foils the aforementioned plan whilst kicking bad guy's *** and bedding the beautiful girl. All formulaic stuff but beloved by generations of Bond fans. `QoS' has these elements parcelled up in a modern day action movie wrapping and the car chases and parkour roof top running scenes make impressive viewing. Craig makes for an macho Bond and there is a gruff hardness to him, rather than the suave sophistication other actors (Connery or Brosnan for example) brought to the role. This film sadly lacks the multitude of gadgets, or even the usual Q segment where they are all introduced. Dench is great as M and the other supporting roles add the right levels of sexiness (from the Bond girls) or sneering evil (from the villains). This is best viewed as the second part to `Casino Royale' and where that film provides the set up, this film provides the release. Both aren't too great in their own rights, but together they make one verygood Bond film. This is worth a look at some point and a worthy addition to the Bond franchise. Lets just hope the next instalment can stand up on it's own two feet and win some of the doubters back.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: When Daniel Craig was first chosen to be the next James Bond, many were skeptical that his rugged looks and uncharacteristic blond hair would in a sense destroy a character that so many people knew and loved.  "Casino Royale" successfully managed to quash those uncertainties with an iron fist and cemented Craig's place in Hollywood history as the renowned secret agent.  "Quantum of Solace", however, loses confidence with its audience not from its star player but from its surprising inability to tell a good story.This 25th in a long line of Bond films is a first in that it is a continuation of the story from the previous film.  Bond (Craig) is still looking to avenge former lover Vesper Lynd's death and in his haste to catch the culprit, he stumbles upon a mysterious organization that bears the heavy hand of a man named Dominic Greene (Amalric), the head of an environmental organization called Green Planet.  Greene, a ruthless businessman with ties to the CIA and the British government, barters a deal with the exiled General Medrano to overthrow Bolivia's existing government in order for Medrano to regain control of his homeland.  Greene's fee is a piece of land that is considered useless to everyone else but is a really a source of great importance to South America.  While tracking Greene's moves, Bond has a run-in with a Spanish beauty named Camille (Kurylenko) who is looking to settle a score of her own.  With both of their missions extremely personal, 007 and Camille work together to take down Greene and Medrano at the cost of their own lives.The screenwriting team from "Casino Royale" have returned (Paul Haggis, Neal Purvis, Robert Wade) and while Haggis was offered an opportunity to direct, he turned it down, stating that writing and directing a film would take too long.  I'm a little disappointed he chose to go this route, as "Quantum of Solace" might've turned out for the better.  Who does take the director's chair this time `round is Marc Forster and a change of directors means a change of pace as well.  Whereas "Casino Royale" director Martin Campbell and his crew supplied superbly choreographed stunts and a suspenseful story coupled with effective editing, Forster has his action sequences switching frames so frequently that the viewer can hardly tell what is going on.  The overall pacing is so expeditious with so many plot points squeezed in that the story can get confusing rather quickly, making it hard to keep up with what's going on.  If you have poor attention to detail or a short attention span, you'll miss a lot of things and get lost very quickly.Daniel Craig is yet again impressive as the indefatigable James Bond, a man who agilely leaps and sprints from here to there, confiscates and crashes cars with panache and exerts deadly force on his enemies.  Amalric is a bit of an enigma as Dominic Greene - he's one of the least interesting onscreen Bond villains and has no distinguishing physical characteristics that Bond villains are so known for (no eye weeping blood, no steel jaw, no fluffy cat in his lap).  Ukrainian actress Olga Kurylenko sports an admirable Spanish accent as Camille and fairs well for an actress who is fairly new to the big screen.  Dench is eloquent as always as M - at this point, anyone else who took this role just wouldn't measure up.Though I am deeply dissatisfied with Forster's approach to this latest Bond installment, I do award a few points for his homage to previous Bond films (the beginning credits are smothered in sultry female silhouettes), most notably "Goldfinger".  Those who remember the infamous death scene in which actress Shirley Eaton's nude body was completely covered in gold paint will recognize Forster's mimicry instantly.Bottom line: Forster's attempt at his first Bond film is fair at best, and I do hope it will be his last attempt.  For a man who directed critically acclaimed films like "Finding Neverland" and "Monster's Ball", I expected better of him.  Here's to hoping that the next Bond film finds a director with better sensibilities as well as a more simplified story.
summary: Too Much Hustle, Not Enough Flow

reviewText: "Quantum of Solace" is the first Bond film in the past 25 years that I did not see more than once in the theater.  Ironically, it's not because it's a significantly worse film than the ones that preceded it; in fact, compared to most, it's much better.  Daniel Craig turns in another strong performance as Bond, obviously older and a little more self-assured this time than in the superior "Casino Royale," even if the film producers keep foolishly trying to find ways to make us think of him more as Steve McQueen than Sean Connery.  (This time it's a sequence involving, of course, a motorcycle.)Part of the challenge was scheduling, I suppose -- finding the time and then finding it again in the theater.  But another, more troubling reality is that the film, as good as it is, is simply not inviting of a second look.  That's paradoxical since Marc Forster's bizarre choice to give it an irritating, hyperactive sensibility almost demands a second or third look just to tell what the heck is going on.  Forster seems ignorant of the fact that one of the joys of watching a Bond film is taking in the production, everything from the clothes to the cars to the sets -- here, you barely get a look at anything before there's another quick, often visually disjointed cut that will make some viewers physically ill.Bond is back in what is probably the first true sequel of the film series, going after the shadowy organization -- now christened Quantum -- responsible for his travails in the previous movie.  A handful of that film's cast, including crocodile-ish Jesper Christensen and charming Giancarlo Giannini, return, but are given less meaty and therefore meaningful roles than before. Christensen comes off less menacing and more wheezy, while poor Giannini suffers a fate that is ultimately just in poor taste and, worse, does little to advance the story.  (The clumsy dialogue also muddies whether he was or wasn't a double agent.)  The Bond girls are beautiful, and likable, though neither has as much impact as Eva Green because their roles aren't written that way, and a few nods to previous Bond films seem more gimmicky than anything else.  Creepy Mathieu Amalric spends most of his time only promising villainy, though Jeffrey Wright and Judi Dench once again prove they are the best Felix Leiter and M, respectively, in decades.The plot, like the one in "Casino Royale," is correctly grounded in reality, but the story is flimsier, with so much of what happens to Bond externalized, despite his quest for vengeance.  Perhaps Forster shouldn't have been so determined to make a Bond film barely more than 90 minutes long -- slower cuts and more story would elevate this film to the status it deserves.  A bright point, though, is David Arnold's score, perhaps his most mature to date.  Overall, though, even some Bond fans, like me, will be challenged to get into the spirit to watch "Quantum of Solace" again; right now, it feels like a meal at a fine restaurant you don't get to savor because someone has reservations for your table in half an hour.  Eating there again under the same conditions doesn't quite seem fun.My guess is the next Bond film will return to more fantasy-driven spectacle, a la "Goldfinger," and we might, indeed, be ready for that sort of Bond film again.  However, I'd implore the producers to choose a director who understands the source material better and to not shy from a story letting Daniel Craig, the toughest Bond since Connery, outshine the gadgets and lame jokes that inevitably will follow.  Going back to an autopilot formula would be a mistake considering the talent the cast can bring to the screen.
summary: It Deserves a Longer, Less Frenetic Cut

reviewText: XXXXXThis film is a sequel to the 2006 film "Casino Royale."  It is not based on a book by the late Ian Fleming.The title of this movie comes from a 1960 short story in Fleming's "For Your Eyes Only" but contains no elements of that short story.It is the 22ND "official" (meaning EON productions) Bond movie with Daniel Craig being the sixth actor to play British MI6 agent James Bond (code number: 007).  This is Craig's second outing as Bond, his first being Bond in "Casino Royale."As with Casino Royale, the action and special effects in this movie are fantastic and very realistic.  This movie is also serious (which I like) and reminded me of the first five excellent, serious Sean Connery Bond movies and the excellent one with George Lazenby as Bond.Unfortunately, nothing in this movie suggests we are watching a Bond movie (except when the end credits roll the James Bond theme is played briefly).  It is just a well-crafted action movie.I did not care for the opening credit sequence and song.  There is no opening gun-barrel walk (but one appears, of all places, at the beginning of the closing credits).Daniel Craig appears to be quite fit for his role as James Bond.  But there is more to Bond than just being fit!  There is none of the Bond savoir-fare or the Bond witticisms that have come to define Bond--James Bond.The villain in this movie does not seem to be very villainous.  As well, the Bond girl seems to have weak acting ability.  Dame Judi Dench as "M" has an expanded role in this movie.  She gives a good, convincing performance.Personally, I don't understand why the Bond music is not more liberally used.  Nothing defines James Bond more than this distinctive music.It is also difficult to follow this movie (in terms of action and plot) at times.  I had to stop and rewind it several times.  (Viewers didn't have this luxury in theatres.)This movie was filmed in location in Italy, Mexico, Panama, Chile, Austria, and England.Finally, the DVD itself (released in 2009) is perfect in picture and audio quality.  It has three disappointing extras.In conclusion, for those who are not James Bond fans, and looking to see a good action movie, this is the movie to see.  However, true Bond fans may ask themselves the following:"Is this a James Bond movie or is this an action movie that happens to have somebody in it named James Bond?"** 1/2(2008;  1 hr, 45 min;  wide screen;  28 scenes)<<Stephen Pletko, London, Ontario, Canada>>XXXXX
summary: Is this a James Bond movie or is it an action movie that has somebody named James Bond in it?

reviewText: Daniel Craig returns for his second outing as James Bond 007 in the epic action/adventure "Quantum of Solace." Continuing the events from the best film in the series, "Casino Royale," "Quantum" has bond chasing down the people behind the death of Vesper, and stumbles on a secret organization codenamed Quantum, a group that's so secret, even MI-6 isn't aware of their existence. Bond ends up tangling with a member of the organization who's bent to take over the water supply of Third World countries. Teaming up with a vengeful Russian, Bond takes on the enemy with the brute force that leaves many dead in its wake, leaving Bond's superiors to wonder if his mission is one of vengeance, and not duty."Quantum of Solace" is not as good as the previous entry, but still proves to be an exciting film. Craig once again proves that he is the definitive Bond, a man who's both charming and brutal. The top notch supporting cast and fine writing also deliver. The film's main weakness are the action sequences. While they are very exciting, the editing is very choppy, and leaves the viewer confused about what is going on until the very end. The story also jumps from one country to another one too many times. At 106 minutes, the film crams almost too much into it's short running time. Still, the film delivers the goods, and Bond fans will find much to appreciate.Movie Grade: B+

reviewText: This is the second movie to star Daniel Craig as James Bond. Though it is not as great as the first movie Casino Royale, it is still a wonderful movie in the series. I remember my first reaction on hearing Daniel Craig was going to be the new Bond, I remember thinking "He's not even cute and definitely not suave." After the first movie, actually only  of the way through, I was captivated and hooked. In this movie "Quantum of Solace," the events start on a few hours after the ending of Casino Royale. The movie starts with an action sequence that involves M. The action scenes are stellar, the plot is as usual an evil person wanting to take over the world. The Sean Connery and Roger Moore's depiction of James Bond was a smooth, suave, lady's man; Coolness personified. The Bond movies featuring Craig are darker and delve deeper into the character and intelligence of Bond. Craig as Bond is totally believable as an agent for an intelligence agency. He's smart, sexy, dangerous and lethal.I hope they have Mr. Craig signed to play Bond into eternity. I just can't imagine anyone doing such a fantastic job of turning this franchise of such a loved character on it's head and being better than it's predecessors.

reviewText: Sadly, since Daniel Craig came onto the scene I've felt increasingly alienated from the franchise. Undoubtedly Craig is a fine actor, but then again so is Al Pacino, Tom Hanks and Michael Sheen, but I'd imagine they've never been serious contenders for the role of 007! Really if Craig were to appear in a Bond flick, he'd be best suited to either the Robert Shaw 'Red Grant' character in From Russia With Love, or that of 006 in Goldeneye - in other words, playing a villian. To have him playing the great man himself is frankly laughable. Aside from my disapproval of Craig as Bond, I can appreciate the merits of 'Casino Royale', I cannot, however, see any such merits in this offering. Anyway, moving on, there's very little in this film to affiliate it with its predecessors, QOS is simply an action movie and not a very good one at that. If we're to have countless set pieces with very little story in-between, at least make the action watchable. The camera filming the proceedings may as well have been placed in a cement mixer - don't get me wrong, from what I could make out, it looked pretty decent fair - although we'll never know because director, Marc Forster, insists on adopting this increasingly annoying practice of shaky camera work coupled with rapid edits - all in a vain effort to make the viewer feel part of the action. For the record, this style of film making is woeful and the sooner this trends dies away the better - incidentally, Forster's previous films weren't action driven and boy does this show! So, a Bond movie without any opening gun barrel, no Q; no gadgets, no moneypenny, minimal use of the Bond theme, an actor who doesn't resemble the pre-conceived image the majority of the audience has of 007 and no utterance of the immortal line "Bond, James Bond" - I'm all for a change of direction in the series, the last two Pierce Brosnan efforts were tired and clichéd. However, instead of working within the world of 007, the producers seem to have thrown in the towel and opted simply to make action movies with a character called James Bond - all this instead of making actual James Bond movies. This is a fundamental mistake and only goes to affirm the notion that, where once 007 dictated the action movie genre, now it simply follows the rest. Oh as for the actual DVD itself, this is nothing spectacular either....

reviewText: Bond movies traditionally come out right around Thanksgiving. This year, "Quantum of Solace" was something Bond fans can truly be thankful for. Contrary to popular opinion, I liked it more thanCasino Royale (Three-Disc Collector's Edition)I liked it more thanDie Another Day (Widescreen Special Edition)(Maybe not more thatThe World Is Not Enough - 2-Disc Ultimate Edition, but since that was the first Bond film I saw theatrically, it has sentimental value for me.) All in all, this is the best experience I've had going to see a Bond movie in a long time.After seeing "Casino Royale", I wasn't sure whether or not I liked Daniel Craig as Bond. Thanks to "Quantum of Solace", I have to say I still don't rate him as highly as Sean Connery or Timothy Dalton, my two favorite Bonds, but I now fully accept him in the role, and he may even be squeaking into a three-way tie for third place with Pierce Brosnan and Roger Moore. In CR, Bond was portrayed as a "blunt instrument", starting out as an elite Double-Oh agent and slowly evolving into the martini-smooth super-spy we've all come to know and love. QoS continues that evolution. 007 is now on the smoother sideof blunt, a thug that looks dashing in a tuxedo (even if he has to steal one) and has a taste for the finer things in life. He also has a very dry sense of humor, more apparent than in CR, but not as over the top as in the Brosnan films. Basically, he's awfully close to the character in Ian Fleming's novels.Like CR, QoS represents a break from tradition concerning the older movies, but at the same time feels more like a traditional Bond film. Bond never introduces himself as "Bond, James Bond", but he never has to. He never orders him martini "shaken, not stirred", but it's implied. And these catch phrase didn't occur in all of the earliest Bond movies, either. All of the other elements are there: the beautiful women (Gemma Arterton and Olga Kurylenko), the beautiful cars (the Aston Martin DBS), and a vast organization (called Quantum) bent on world domination.Unfortunately, the movie's weakest moments are the action scenes. While CR director Martin Campbell has some experience in the genre, QoS director Marc Forester (Finding Neverland (Widescreen Edition),Stranger Than Fiction) is more used to directing dramas. While some of the action scenes are inventive, the decision to film all of them using a shakyCloverfieldhandy-cam approach was a mistake. The most inventive action scenes would have been improved by a more traditional steady cam approach, while the shaky cam doesn't really add anything to the moreconventional scenes.  And the hyper editing makes the scenes almost impossible to follow during the initial viewing.  Admittedly, it forces viewers to not shut their minds off during chase scenes, but it also lacks visual appeal.On the other hand, the character scenes really work well, and simple scenes, such as Bond spying from a tall scaffolding or shimmying across the wrong side of a balcony to avoid capture, become the film's best action moments. The movie is filled with welcome references to the older movies and Fleming novels (including an unmistakableGoldfinger - 2-Disc Ultimate Editionreference). The Bond girls are great. Olga Kurylenko is beautiful and exotic, while fresh-faced Gemma Arterton's younger Bond girl steals the show, even as a secondary character. Her innocence and vulnerabilitymake her unique as a Bond girl, and she's one of the best Bond women in a long time.  Possibly, in my opinion, the best Bond girl ever. Matthieu Almaric's villian is the most realistic baddie in the series. Jack White and Alicia Key's duet "Another Way to Die" is one of the best Bond theme songs ever, on par with Chris Cornell's theme from the previous film. And the classic gun barrel, as in CR, appears in a way that makes it new and exciting again.Finally, QoS's short run time, just under two hours compared to CR's massive just over two-and-a-half, is brief and sweet and ends just in time not to overstay its welcome. All in all, despite the flaws I could pick out, I left the theater grinning like an idiot.
summary: Bond is Back, and That's Something for Fans to be Thankful For
